150467732.review:
For most of the game, Owlboy didn't really click with me. The are a lot of aspects of the game that I didn't like:
- Combat isn't all that interesting or challenging. The player character can fly and has a very short dodge cooldown, so enemies rarely ever felt threatening.
- Player flight also means that there isn't really any platforming in Owlboy. When the game adds hazards that the player has to carefully fly around, it ends up being more tedious than engaging.
- Stealth is stupidly simple. There's only ever one path forward, enemies don't have complex movement patterns, there's no distraction mechanic or any way to bypass by an enemy other than simply waiting for them to look away. It's more of a test of patience than skill. 
- It's seriously easy to get lost in Owlboy. Many sections of the game are designed like puzzles, and the game doesn't always do a great job communicating the correct path forward.
- The game doesn't always do a great job of creating safe "room" transition points. This essentially means that, when moving between two areas, It's possible to get hit by an enemy you couldn't react to, since the camera was still transitioning into the new area from the old area. This could easily be avoided by making sure enemies are never anywhere close to the border between two rooms. Other platformers, even platformers made by much larger studios, do this same exact thing, but it still annoys the heck out of me every time I see it. 
- And, as a final note, the writing is painfully, obnoxiously cheesy in some moments. Characters don't speak like independently thinking people. So much of the dialogue feels overly-dramatic or out of place. It's the type of story that you skim through as quickly as possible, in the hopes that the story gets better later on.

That being said, why would I give the game a positive review if it had so much to complain about? Well to my surprise, the story did get better later on. In fact, Owlboy's endgame is actually really good. The last few bosses are seriously fun and challenging to fight. During the final level, the game becomes much less confusing to traverse and even removes the player's flight abilities to create some actual platforming challenges. The game's ending was unexpectedly emotional and beautiful, and I ended up finishing the game with a positive view of the game despite its early frustrations. Owlboy isn't a *great* game, and I couldn't recommend it to everyone. But, a stupendous amount of work and passion went into this game, and the ending in particular is good enough that you might just like it.

146146142.review:
In short, this is a short, very polished game that will make you feel in the presence of a respectable adventure. While not a neat finish for a game, piecing it together can make the game feel a bit better as a whole. It also takes the realization that this was a 10 year passion project that D-Pad Studio barely survived.

This is not worth $25 territory; however, it is definitely worth it as a game around $10-15 if you are up for a game with well written characters.

The primary part you are getting from this game is story. It feels like a book, not in theme, but in how it paces its story and wraps up fairly quickly. Each character is meaningful even if they can be somewhat 2D at times. It's not a very deep underdog story; however, it is decently executed.

The combat in this game is moderately ok. Not difficult by any means. You will find common enemies quite easy, but bosses in this game are actually quite balanced once you solve their patterns. The game makes up for combat with pretty decent stealth sections of the game. At first, it feels restrictive; however, it does not treat you being found as instant death. In fact, later on you have a few different options in how you maintain your stealth.

This game is completely linear outside of its overworld. You are pushed from key point to key point without too much say in the matter, and the game does use convenient metroidvania-like blocks to keep you from progressing where you are not meant to yet. This game doesn't seem to fit the mystery of exploration that metroidvanias have though. It only really takes the unlockable pathway concept.

The game's "coins" are a treasure hunter's completionist sink. If you like searching for the last bits of stuff, it has you covered. None of the coins are missable. 

The payoff of the ending: I'm going to put it like this. This game had a ton of cut content. The developers did wrap together an ending that does work; however, it can feel a bit off if you don't pay attention to the main character's growth. I don't consider this a major spoiler as I believe this part of the game is best found before completing the ending. It plainly shows one to you in the first dungeon. This game has 1 bit of extra content that can be found by gathering 3 key items. You have to retreat before actually finishing the game if you want to explore for what it is. 

There is no true ending to chase after. See this game for what it is. It's the best a dev team could push together after having to cut quite alot. And, while not perfect, this game is solidly worth your time if you want an uplifting story. 

I'm glad to have seen how Otus, the Owl boy, grew as a character. I hope even 7 years after this game came out, a few more people can find the same just-right satisfaction from it.

Owlboy is satisfying and fun. The characters are great (the eventual scene with Asio was incredibly touching) and the music is really good. 

There are some minor fiddly bits that I didn't enjoy so much, the first one being that combat is annoying in boss battles) - if you get hit and lose your gunner you have to recover mid-air, and then potentially rotate through all your 3 gunners to get back to the one you were using. The second are the much-maligned darkness sections. Yes, they're bad. Not awful, just... bad.

The plot tries to cram far too much in - it starts out with a great protagonist who makes mistakes and seeks to resolve them against a near-unbeatable enemy but tries to put a bunch of additional information and catastrophes that only really arrive in the 11th hour and completely change the focus of what you were doing. This isn't a disaster for a game like this but it's a shame to see all this interesting characterisation set aside in favour of a plot that ends up feeling shoehorned in.

The core mechanics are fun and good, though. Some interesting puzzles, solid and smooth platforming (if you fly are you really platforming?), gorgeous pixel art, and genuinely an experience that I enjoyed tremendously. Not long, but ~90% of the game is just solid fun and characters you'll wish you had more time with.

Is it worth your money? 

Yes.

It's not a *bad* game. Really, in the time between buying it and playing it my interests changed. A semi-linear exploration adventure doesn't really work for me these days, and I don't have the patience for getting lost. The gameplay's a little clumsy but fine, though i think it leans too much on your companions for the Mario 2 thing to really be meaningful and worth the hassle; and it's probably too hard for the game's actual target audience? No control remapping is really unfortunate, and you can't use keyboard at all if your controller's plugged in.

The main reason I felt unsatisfied however, has to do with the narrative. I came away with the feeling that this game doesn't really understand its own heart: You start off as one of the loneliest, most hated people in the world, and gradually find companionship with other lonely and hated folks. You randomly stumble across a magic trinket that teleports friends to you, a pretty frivolous power in anyone else's hands, and gain the ability to cooperate like no one else. This *should* be what the story is about, but, instead it's just a really standard save-the-world story.

Yknow, to save the world that hates you. No attention is called to the irony, and Otus is never questioned on this. No explicit effort is made to forgive the world either. I know Otus is this incorruptible good boy, but this kid should be *deathly* depressed. I stopped talking to town NPCs pretty quickly because *I* was getting depressed. And feeling nothing positive for the world as you save it *really* weakens the climax.

Meanwhile, this theme of loneliness and overcoming it is barely followed up on, and what little followup it gets is pretty weak in my opinion, so I felt like none of it came together in the end. Also, as one of the few likeable characters, I really wanted to talk to Solus more.

The thing that really drove me to downvote the game though is [spoiler]I'm just *not* interested in forgiving Asio, for frick's sakes. I think most people with an abusive parent would understand, they do not deserve to be heard. I don't care that it's the end of the game, there is no comfort in it. Similar things apply to the stickbug family.[/spoiler]

There's a bit of lore to sink your teeth into if you're into that, but I feel like I get the gist and I don't think it's worth it.

As you play you'll gather allies which function as your weapons, hoisting them up and carrying them around which makes the combat a bit more interesting if awkward at times.

It has a classic PC platformer feel and I was well on my way to a pretty exhaustive playthrough. It is very retro in the sense that there's not much to it beyond the platforming, shooting, and some basic puzzle solving but that didn't bother me. The story takes itself a bit too seriously and despite how cartoony it is everyone seems to always be yelling and criticising you, and there are some very gritty sections which conflict with the more magical tone the art style is going for.

Personally I rage quit after trying to do the Boguin Run, a mini game that has you doing a high speed agility course. The input here is completely different from the rest of the game and it requires you to memorise inputs through brute force trial and error, needing a perfect run to complete. It's such a difficult challenge in the middle of this game which feels entirely unrelated and yet it's such a long and difficult course it really distracted me from the game and was annoying enough that I ended up putting the game down entirely.

At this point, after 15.5 hours of playtime, I have seen and done all in this game and collected every achievement. This game, for me, was overall a joy to play. There were a couple frustrating moments and I really didn't like the optional cannon mini-game (But hey, I wanted to be a completionist) but all in all, this was a truly great game!

First of all, its an absolute JOY to your senses, both visual and auditory!

Soundtrack: 10/10 (Really, it's fantastic and I couldn't find one flaw!)
Pixel-Art: 9.8/10 (I held back just a little because there were a couple very minor imperfections)

As far as the actual game itself, it was a great game! Its not a masterpiece like say, Chrono Trigger, but it was a truly wonderful game! It's a nostalgic old-school side-scroller with its own take. There's not much platforming, technically because its designed around the fact that you can fly almost limitlessly. The world is beautiful and varied and it basically utilizes side-scrolling shooter combat where you aim, move around, and shoot. There's also a Dash attack and a spin attack that's mostly used for stunning or interacting with the environment. 

Combat: 7/10 (Hardly the shining strong suit of the game, but not bad.)
Boss Design: 8/10 (These were mostly a lot of fun and varied enough to keep me on my toes. Certain bosses were much more fun than others though.)
Level Design: 7/10 (These were beautiful and a joy to explore with the exception of a little too many spots that were more frustrating than fun. That's what held it back from greatness. I'd still say it was good overall.)

And last but not least, there's the story. I was surprised there was as much of a story as there was. Some have been critical of parts of it but as a whole, I really enjoyed every moment of it and heavily enjoyed the characters' interactions and dialogue so...

Story: 9/10 (Outstanding and fun! Not perfect but close enough for me to care about it and feel invested in a short game. That's an achievement, I think.)

Overall: 8.5 (It's a really great game that's easily worth experiencing at the very least, once! Its evident how much the developers really cared and as a work of art, I truly appreciated it.)

[h1][b]Owlboy[/b][/h1]
[b]Unos de lo primeros indies metroidvanias que pusieron la base para lo que conocemos hoy día.[/b]

[h2][b][u]Introducción[/u][/b][/h2]

Owlboy a pesar de sus años, tiene unos detalles, una jugabilidad y una historia que le hacen sombra a muchos de los juegos de hoy en día, además, su duración no tan alargada como muchos títulos que suelen aparecer, hace que sea bastante factible jugártelo en un par de ratos. 

[h2][b][u]Sensaciones y detalles del juego[/u][/b][/h2]

El juego tiene un nivel de detalle y un mimo en su pixel-art que solo podemos quitarnos el sombrero ante D-Pad Studio. Transmitiendo unos escenarios muy vivos y llenos de cosas y sobretodo muy variados, y es que en su alrededor de 10 horas de duración, tenemos diferentes biomas que aprovechan la dirección artística del juego y sus mecánicas de manera muy inteligente. 

Y es que aunque pueda parecer que el juego ha envejecido mal, lo hace todo demasiado bien, si que es verdad, que en ningún momento vamos a tener un desafío delante que nos haga tirar el mando por la ventana como puede pasar en algunos juegos de los que salen últimamente (quitando el momento del minijuego OPCIONAL del cañón, que la verdad que está diseñado por un psicópata)

La historia, los personajes, los escenarios, la verdad que hay poco que reprochar al juego, muy disfrutable y sobretodo por el precio que lo sueles encontrar últimamente y las posibilidades que te da, más que suficiente. 

Además de todo esto, tiene una banda sonora que quita el hipo, teniendo algunos temas de lo más interesantes, como algunos de la recta final del juego. 

[h3][b][u]Pros[/u][/b][/h3]
[list][*]El pixel art y la dirección artística.
[*]Jugabilidad a prueba de los años.
[*]La historia aún siendo corta en ningún momento se siente con un ritmo atropellante ni nada, todo perfecto.[/list]
[h3][b][u]Contras[/u][/b][/h3]
[list][*]El minijuego del cañón, está hecho por un psicópata.
[*]La dificultad en algunos momentos, y acostumbrados a algunos juegos de hoy en día más desafiantes, puede saber a poco.[/list]

[h2][b][u]Conclusión[/u][/b][/h2]

125241752.review:
I'll start off with one important disclaimer: 
I find it difficult to rate this game and say whether I would or would not recommend it to others. I'll explain why shortly, but in the end, I feel like there were more things that turned me off, than sparked my interest in this game and part of it is probably how I usually play games like these - going for all steam achievements if possible. I also treat this as a way of checking the game's quality because the more I focus on achievements, and less on the story and gameplay itself, the less enjoyable those aspects are in my eyes. With that out of the way, here's the proper review.

Let's begin with the good qualities of the game:
The graphics are beautiful, the animations are smooth and well-made and the music ties it all together very very nicely. The story starts off slow but it picks up the pace in the 2nd half, resulting in a good climax. My only grime with it would be the very final scene where the devs used a very cliche move that made me doubt my previous judgement about the quality of the story, but I'll say more about it in the 2nd part of the review.
Overall, if I were to rate the game simply by the three things I mentioned - visuals, music and story - I'd give it an 8/10. If you're looking for a casual game to take in wonderful pixel art and not have to worry about difficult combat or hard puzzles, I think it's a solid production, although I'd wait with buying it until it's on sale.

The things I did not enjoy about Owlboy:
There's a lot. At first, let's focus on movement and exploration - the core elements of the game. If you want to move at any meaningful pace you have to constantly spam your dash button, which is not ideal to say the least. Some areas become off-limits after you've gone through them once, meaning if you miss a collectible, you have to reload an old save. Areas themselves don't have much variety. The dungeons are cool I guess, but the overworld is disappointing because every platform and background is almost identical but with a different denisty of shrubbery and thorns. Backtracking, a huge part of finding all collectibles, is a chore and a boring one at that because of this, and some tighter passages in certain hazardous areas can be rather annoying.
The combat. I know it's not a combat-based game but there is a combat system and so I am to rate it (spoiler alert: it's not great). You get to fight using 3 different characters, all specialising in a different thing. Unfortunately, for most of them it's only a case of one firing mode which gets stale very very quickly and by the time you finish the first major story sequence, you'll see each encounter with enemies as yet another thing to tick off, instead of a fun and engaging experience. Speaking of enemies, their designs are pleasing visually, but the attacks leave a lot to ask for. Getting hit by anything sends you flying as if you were playing Super Smash Bros and hitting a wall during that time leaves you temporarily stunned and unable to recover or do anyting. This gives enemies plenty of time to surround you, and since you drop your companions upon getting hit, by the time you pick them back up to shoot the adversaries, your i-frames disappear and you go ping-ponging around the room once more. Enemies can also gank up on screen transitions and while you can't see them because the camera is panning out, they can hit you and knock you back into the previous screen - very annoying. There were multiple very disappointing mini-bosses that were more like wave rooms where you have to fight one enemy, then two enemies of that kind and so on until you beat a wave of 6 enemies. Proper bosses are more interesting but they're also somewhat hectic because you can dash through some of their attacks but not all of them and also the attacks you can dash through sometimes still hit you... it's a mess is what I'm getting at. Not great, as I said.
Unique powers. A staple of a metroidvania. There hardly are any and they only come in the form of a new companion. The game is surprisingly linear and so, new obstacles only appear once you already have a new companion that can help you through them. This takes away from the interest metroidvanias spark in you of seeing a place you can't reach. You know you should be able to get there eventually so you're just looking for a power or tool that would enable this and it makes for an interesting dynamic. Owlboy doesn't have that.
Collectibles. There are a lot of them and they're all useless. Thousands of coins for upgrades that are negligable except for the final one. 9 upgrades in total, 3 of them are not even upgrades, 2 are borderline unfair for the game's standards, the rest are whatever.
Achievements! This is what I meant with "my specific playstyle". I like getting all achievements in metroidvanias. You'd assume that in a story-driven game, there would be at least some achievements for finishing a story event or beating the game but not in Owlboy. In here you will find 12 achievements that have nothing to do with the story and include taking a random shell to a spot in the middle of nowhere to waste a minute of your life watching a pointless animation with no story implications. Fun stuff, I love wasting my time on useless interactions.
Finally - the characters and some parts of the overall gameplay. The characters are all dull. One of the first people you meet is a jerk that you're going to hate for the rest of the game and said jerk made the final cutscene anticlimactic and dumb in my opinion. The rest of the cast is really generic and the only truly unique characters are Solus (someone who appears maybe 4 times in the story and yet is a crucial character), and Twig. I wish Solus was given more spotlight, maybe giving him some more backstory but oh well. I also mentioned story sequences. When you first boot up the game, you're met with one of those sequences. It makes up 1/3rd of the game's entire storyline. While it's still ongoing, you can't backtrack, you can't return to the shop to trade collectibles for potentially-helpful hp upgrades and you have to go through the entire thing to get some freedom. If you miss a collectible in one certain spot, you're screwed and have to replay around half of this story sequence.

Overall, the game has more things that I dislike about it, than I enjoyed about it. They may seem like small details, but said details are what make or break a good experience, and for the majority of my time spent on Owlboy, I wasn't having a good time. It's not a terrible game, but you have to set your expectations low and only pick it up if you want to play casually for the story, not for the achievements. If you're an achievement hunter - don't bother. If you're here for the story - wait for a sale.

122524752.review:
Amazing artwork, a wild gameplay adventure, and a stumbling story of illogical characters.

Screenshots and video do and don't do the artwork justice. Simply put, this is the best pixel-style 2D art you can find in a game. It's not just the art itself. It's not just the animations themselves. It's understanding how to use both in the context of presenting a video game experience. Interacting with it from from just walking around, to watching a staged in-game cutscene is nonstop awe inspiring beauty. Amazing what they pulled off. Despite being a 2D platformer, this is a cinematic experience more than anything. It has all the vibes of a modern AAA blockbuster with scripted sequences, while being a 2D retro/indie style. It's stunning how they made it all work. The visuals are truly bonkers good. You seriously cannot oversell them. 

The gameplay that comes with the visuals is competent. The game leans heavily on a crutch of so-so storytelling. So the gameplay does limp at times because of that. The pacing of when you're actually involved can be a stop and go drive down a bumpy back road. The sudden swings in required tactics and interactions can make easy sequences turn into trial and error. Or easier bosses seem daunting at first. There's nothing wrong with the controls and tools at your disposal. They build up great and are fun to wield. You're just left wishing there was more flow to the when and where, as well as consistency, in which you got to use them.

I called the story telling a crutch because while it's a wholly unique world and they present you fantastic lore that you're happily buying into... But the character motivations are downright silly. Maybe the writer's had a reason for it or people read deeper into the whole presentation than I'm willing to (or I'm the one reading too deep into it...) But the silly humor bled too far into ALL the characters. Nearly every character, including the ones of importance, had completely out of left field turns or redemption arcs. Every character had a moment that was completely cruel and one that was completely soft begging for sympathy. With nothing in between or any hint of nuance. Whether it was a boss or somebody in your crew; You had as many reasons to want to help them as you did to despise them. It could've just been all 'cartoon' fun if the game was gameplay heavy, but the game wanted to be a narrative first and foremost. You were reading dialogue and watching cutscenes as much as you were playing. It chose to be story centered. So it was really really off putting and harder to invest in with such wild swings of motivation for each and every character. It was already a repetitive annoyance quite early on and was a persistent gimmick all the way through to the end. Seriously. Every. Character.

But it IS just a 'light' and 'fun' indie 2D platformer game in the end, no matter what the presentation was doing. So I can just appreciate it all on face value. And my what a looker that face is! Stunning visuals. Fun gameplay when you're doing it. And an original enough world to overlook plenty else in the writing. Most definitely a thumbs up and full recommendation. Little disappointed, but yet intrigued, to see their next upcoming title is some sort of party game. This is definitely a crew to keep an eye on. Both eyes.

Owlboy is a charming 2D Shooter Platformer/Metroidvania whose pixel art and music design leave a lasting impression on the player. 

Gameplay-wise, it is very enjoyable. Most of the time the player will be flying around the different areas and dungeons focusing more on shooting at enemies. The different characters you meet along the way act as an unlock to new abilities, which can be very fun to switch through and try out in different scenarios. There are a few sections where the difficulty ramps up unexpectedly, both for boss fights and for navigating through the levels, which can sometimes get frustrating. For players interested in the Metroidvania aspect of the game, I'd say it doesn't have much of an impact other than exploring to collect the Buccanary Coins and Golden disks, which go towards unlocking minor buffs to your abilities (as well as a few cosmetic items) and story elements, respectively. 

Owlboy's level design is generally pretty straightforward and most areas of interest are directly off of the main path. The dungeon design feels very similar to a Legend of Zelda game, with solving puzzles opening up the next section in the dungeon. One downside that becomes noticeable in latter half of the game is that there isn't a map, but this is really only an issue when backtracking to collect any coins or disks you may have missed the first time through. 

The story of Owlboy comes across as a bit hit-or-miss. Some plot points seemingly coming out of nowhere as a contrived way to introduce drama, while the rest of the time the story is held up by its interesting characters and the interactions between them. 

Overall, I would recommend playing Owlboy as a casual experience that delivers on great atmosphere, with its art and music, and enjoyable gameplay.

118951864.review:
This game is beautiful, but I don't understand why it had to be a game.  

After seeing some e3 footage, the game seemed to have a lot going for it. 
A minimalistic idea fully fleshed out in a very Zelda-esque world. A great sense of identity and a slightly unique twist on gameplay. This looked to follow suit on some other indie gems of the time. 
Sadly thats not the case. 

This game has very obvious strenghts. It focuses on the inscination: The visuals and the Soundtrack. 
Its all beautifully realised, with real attention to detail. The vistas are stunning and rich. The music is fully orchestrated and sounds at times mysterious and simple, at others very grand and impressive. 

The weaknesses are similarly obvious. This is a game that you shouldn't play, but instead should watch someone else play. The game's unique mechanic is that you can fly, carry around others, and use them to attack (shoot) instead of attacking yourself. This seems oddly at war with the leveldesign, where you spent most of your times in caverns and caves being very restrictive of your movement and general game progression. 
Switching out who youre carrying is rarely necessary, since the gameplay really never evolves , with you having to swtich to different characters. You can just pick one and stay with him, unless its one of the rare Situations where you can't use all of your characters. This makes it so that the different characters are effectively just different weapons (pistol, shotgun,...)

The enemies seem to be poorly designed as well. Some have unique mechanics that usually turn into a tedium pretty quickly. Others are just bullet sponges, which have no actual way of attacking you. 
Bosses usually consist of 3 phases, that, all in all, display about 4-5 moves, with very simple bullet-hell-like dodging patterns. These bosses are spread pretty evenly about the game, and sometimes make pretty surprising introductions (Some of them making the game lag), but they feel largely disconnected to the world or the stroy. 

Exploration is sadly almost never encouraged or even possible. The games levels are linear, and the world it's set in just gives a slight illusion of openess with a big hub-area. After you leave that hub area you will find yourself quickly gated, by some powerup check or other. This of course is all in service of the story, that has to happen in a certain order to make sense. This destroys a lot of the illusion of an open world very quickly, even though there are some hidden paths to collectibles. These can be used to get some minor upgrades and cosmetics. 

The game seems to defy itself. 
The art and music makes you want to explore and see the world, but the world is linear and closed, largely consisting of tunnels to fight enemies in. 
The Story seems the centerpiece of it all, telling a simple engaging story with some deeper subplot.  But the game never gives you any insentive to interact with the characters, and goes off on random tangents for what feels like most of the game. 

This game could've been something.

I think this game is a good example of a very clear difference between trying something new, different, and experimental and being an actual solid experience to play.
While I think Owlboy's conception is something to be appreciated, and it has some of the best pixel art I have seen in a game, ever, playing the game and controlling the character can feel clunky. 
The concept of Owlboy is that your character's only way with interacting with the world is picking up stuff and flying. You can't attack enemies on your own; you need to carry other people with weapons to do that. While the concept is nice, and ties in with the whole theme of Owlboy being about how cooperation and accounting for your weaknesses in a group makes both the individual contribution and the group effort that much stronger, in practice controlling Otus feels disjointed. This might've been just a 'me' problem, I chose to play the game with a controller so maybe playing on a keyboard alleviates this. I just felt like I could never switch between the characters fast enough in a boss fight, or the momentum of the game would stop for me to precisely aim at something. The design is clunky, but it's not sloppy. It just feels like there is some fine tuning to the core design of controlling Otus and his friends that could have massively overhauled the gameplay of Owlboy and made for a much more enjoyable experience.
I want to like Owlboy. The decade or so of work put into the look of the game absolutely shines. When I first got to the Owl Temple, and the camera pans up to show the giant statue of the owl, with all of it's incredible detail and polish, I was floored. Some of the best pixel art I've ever seen is in this game, hands down. The story Owlboy presents is also nice. I wouldn't give it a fucking award or anything, but it's solid. I don't know that it's trying to be an award-winning story, now that I think about it. Character interactions also tend to be weighed down by the trope of being treated like shit by others, and it isn't helped by the fact that it feels like  problem that every character in Owlboy deals with. Though, by the end of the game, it's not really something that drags the whole experience down for me substantially. 
One little thing I wanna say is that I appreciated the approach to the character Molstrum. He's a/the major antagonist set on acquiring some macguffins to end the world. He's not a particularly special character, but the game creates this air around him that he's so powerful and strong that all of the other characters would have no chance of defeating him. You never actually have a standard 'boss fight' with him (although you could argue the ending sequence to be the Molstrum's 'boss fight' but shut up), and, after thinking about it, I feel like that strengthens Molstrum's presence as an antagonist. He's so strong that the protagonists avoid direct combat with him, instead trying to collect the macguffins faster than he does, and steal the ones he has.
I heard that the concept of Owlboy came about from Simon Anderson (the art director and creator of Owlboy) wondering what a game would be like if it was only the flying from the Super Leaf power up in Super Mario Bros. 3. Owlboy is a story-driven metroidvania title and it executes its purpose very well. It has a beautiful story, beautiful soundtracks, and a pixel art style that looks wonderful. I believe it's safe to assume that Owlboy is not for everyone due to the fact that there are so many dialogue in it. If you're thinking of buying this game for its gameplay alone, you may not get what you expect for the gameplay it offers is mediocre at best. You can fly, pick up your buddies to use them as weapons, pick up some objects to use them to your advantage and that's it. However, they managed to keep it interesting with various boss battles in my opinion. Puzzles are quite interesting, too. 

Story is where this game shines best. It has its own unique universe where owls used to be the most sophisticated species of the earth, but their arrogance caused the continents to get separated and float into the sky thus carried civilization with them. What if you're from a species that cannot fly? Well, good luck then. There are also hostile robots that call themselves "Pirates" and they cause trouble for the other people. I won't spoil anything but they have a motive behind their actions. 

The protagonist, Otus, is the most interesting thing about the story. He was born mute and although he's trying his best, he is constantly getting blamed by his teacher Asio for ruining things, which leads him to have self-esteem issues. Now isn't that perfectly relatable for the most of us? The whole story revolves around Otus' struggle within and he wants to prove himself to the people and most importantly, his teacher Asio. Does he succeed? Well, that's left to player's interpretation, I guess. In short, Owlboy is both heartwarming and a heartbroken experience that should be experienced by anyone who is having trouble about making inner peace with themselves.

From imalwaystired.blog

There are only a few games in life that allow the player to feel a certain type of emotions and Owlboy by D-Pad Studios is that game. The player starts the game as Otus, a mute Owl, who lives in the floating village of Vellie. Otus' mentor, Asio is portrayed as the parent figure that gives Otus the toughest of love, for example, constantly bringing to light Otus' inadequacies . The adventure begins when robot pirates under the command of the infamous Molstrom unexpectedly attack a nearby city. Otus and newly acquired friend Geddy set of to understand the motive of the robot pirates. Owlboy takes a different approach to normal storytelling by allowing the player to discover for themselves through the silent storytelling.

This game looks damn good. The game is not restricted by the 8 and 16- bit style or its color palette. From the Vellie to the Owl Temples and Molstrom's pirate ship, the colors are absolutly phenomenal. Even when Owlboy was to pan the camera out, the pixel resolution does not miss a step and always looks fantastic.

Even towards the end, when everything is looking bleak and the plot has taken a turn for the worse, Owlboy consistently delivers a beautiful and awe-inspiring game.

The controls are actually pretty standard. Otus casually jogs, can attack and can fly. It does get on the annoying side that Otus is pretty slow and rolling makes him pick up speed, so I found myself a lot of the time rolling to get along faster.

Owlboy may have one of the best soundtracks in a video game. The orchestral sounds are perfect in every encounter and are pleasing to the ear. The drums heats up when situations are serious and  the flutes, piano are calming when there is a lull in combat. Jonathan Geer deserves immense praise for the work that he has done with the Owlboy.

Owlboy was a joy to play. It contains a hearfelt story that tackles themes of disabilities and friendship without compromising storytelling or gameplay to get the theme across. The ten hours that I had put into Owlboy reminded me why I love these kind of games. I felt for Otus and I believed in the adventure that he went on. It made me feel when Asio consistently criticized Otus. When Otus and his friends triumphed, I felt like I had also won. With its exceptional characters, music, plot and stlye, Owlboy is a game that I will always recommend to those wanting a 2D adventure game.

99056214.review:
Here's the catch with this game: I understand the game took 9 years to make and developers probably put their heart and soul into this, but I have to judge this like any other game. 

The music is great and the graphics are charming. Certainly much better 2D pixel art game than any game out there. 

Storywise I have some gripes. While the game's story is good, it feels rather slow paced, as the game starts throwing explanations only near the end of the game while most of the game you are like "Who, what, where?" and even after beating the game you still have some questions. There are some holes that would have been probably explained more if they added some kind of archive or library. It's not bad it's just don't expect the greatest story ever told.

Gameplay. Okay, this is where it goes into "some people love it some people hate it". The platforming has a unique concept where instead of normal platforming you can fly. This concept seems good on paper but there is a flaw: every time you get hit, your character gets stun locked and gets thrown in a random direction. This is my problem. The devs did make it less annoying by adding temporary invincibility when you get damaged, but it still brings frustrations.

But probably my biggest problem of the game is collectables. The game has certain number of coins and there are limited number of upgrades in the game. For a metroidvania, you would expect a large number of upgrades, like Castlevania SotN or Ori and the Blind Forest, but this game has 6 upgrades. 6?! Only six? You get 5 upgrades as you collect coins but you get the 6th one after you collect all the coins which will take hours and hours of going back and forth in the dungeons... and its not really worth it, only if you want to have 5% rare achievement.

But do I still recommend this game? If you are a fan of metroidvania, yes. If you want something that will have a great story, I'd recommend Dust An Elysian Tail instead. I won't give "Not recommended" because I don't think the game is bad, I just think the game is decent, but just not mindblowingly good like every other comment here says so.

As a final note, I do not think the game is worth 23$. The game lacks more content, and there are other metroidvanias that are cheaper and offer more hours and better story pacing. If you want my honest price, it would be 10$. The game takes about 10-13 hours to beat. There should be more content and more upgrades

97907863.review:
What looks to be childish on the surface, has amazingly deep character development with fully fleshed out and realised characters and for that, huge kudos to the devs.
It has some quirks and rough edges, but none of these overshadow the emotional rollercoaster the main story takes the player on.

From the onset it has an emotionally heavy beginning, and I mean that in a well executed way as it depicts toxicity in all of its ugly shades. 
The story touches on some powerful feelings of loss, despair, grief, guilt, bullying, depression and so much more, all of which come within the context of adolescence.

On the flip side, there is conscious effort in place to emphasise what behaviours and thinking can combat those negative emotions through the charming way it tells the tale.
It was beautiful to see courage, compassion, power of friendship and companionship, and most of all, forgiveness rise and play such a huge role here in order to overturn the aforementioned negativity.

And it's crazy because it's all hidden behind a veil of adorably animated characters. 

Which speaking of, I adore the fact that so much effort went into animating all the characters. You can see them carrying their hearts on their little sleeves as they cower in terror, lower their ears in fear or visibly perk up when happy.

Here, pixel art is absolutely gorgeous and timeless in its execution and reminds me of Chrono Trigger, Metal Slug and generally the golden age of SNES/Megadrive level pixel quality.

It also has a downright beautiful orchestral music score which perfectly complements each level and scene. 
I wouldn't label it as 'catchy' in an earworm way, but it's definitely a soundtrack made for joyful and easy listening (except the boss fights of course).

Track Recommendations:[list]
[*]Strato Theme
[*]Mesos Theme[/list]

Audio wise, sound effects of enemies being blasted away feels chunky and gritty, and collecting coins sounds like something out of Mario or Sonic - perfectly encapsulating the gaming era it's inspired by.

The unique aspect of this metroidvania is that you fly around and 'hot swap' party members you carry. Each one of them has a unique way of helping you both in combat and in accessing new pathways. Flying itself did not feel 'floaty' to me as pressing "B" performed a dash which was literally how I got around everywhere quickly.
For those wanting real speed and real use of the floating rings, give the cannon minigame a try!

Calling this a Metroidvania is a long stretch however. There's very little to actually 'explore' other than along a fairly linear story progressing path. 
Another way to describe it is that it feels like a platformer where all levels are made to lead you one way - the story way. Going off the beaten path is short and usually results in a shortcut or chest full of coins and not a power-up directly. Though it's worth mentioning that collecting coins is actually how you unlock new upgrades through the game's one store.

This is probably why there's no real map though, there just aren't that many zones to explore that you couldn't get back to quickly.

All in all, I thoroughly enjoyed my time with Owlboy. It made me feel things, and so for that it's essentially art. Feel free to experience it yourself and see what you think of it.

+Music was atmospheric while also servicing cut-scenes very well.

~SPOILERS~

I personally really liked the game! Most of the combat, movement, Metroidvania discovery, that was really great, and the story was also a lot more interesting than I thought it would be. With all of those positive feelings in mind, I have two big gripes:

1.) Frustrating sections of gameplay.
There were some unnecessarily punishing sections of the game, like an area where you have to solve a puzzle in less than 10 seconds or you die from poison gas and have to restart. Having such strict time constraints on a puzzle all of a sudden felt frustrating, not rewarding.

2.) Asio. (Sorry, this part ended up being a lot longer than I meant it to be-- whoops!)
I should clarify immediately: I'm totally fine with Asio being a jerk. I think a lot of negative reviews of the game have cited his behavior towards Otus as a bad aspect of the game, which I don't think is the case. In fact, I was excited at how dark the game got early on, since I think honest portrayals of mental illness and abusive relationships in video games aren't touched very often. And for that, I applaud the developers.
What I'm frustrated with is specifically the very end of the game where Asio and Otus have their final conversation. In my reading of the game, I felt like one of Otus's main obstacles is poor mental health and self-esteem, which is personified in Asio, his abusive mentor who is the source of all of his self doubts. Quite literally every encounter Otus has with Asio throughout the game is negative and demeaning-- until the end when Asio suddenly flips the script and pretends like he believed in Otus the whole time. Personally, whenever Asio was on screen, I felt visceral anxiety and frustration (in a way that I think is intentional). So the fact that Asio was never confronted for his abusive behavior, or expresses any apology for his actions, made this inspiring conversation between Otus and Asio-- which ends the whole emotional arc of the game-- feel reeeeally hollow. Furthermore, this is the moment when Otus overcomes the other signifier for his poor self-esteem: his muteness. His inability to speak forces him to be a passive spectator in his own relationships, unable to express opinions about the people and events around him (this is mentioned many times, like how he can't express opinions about his new spider friend to their family). So in the ending, he's finally able to speak, and I'm thinking, "oh, it's about to go down! Otus is gonna use his newfound gift of speech to really give Asio a peace of his mind and confront him and put a fitting end to that emotionally-charged relationship..." but he's still a passive spectator! All he does is ask if his friends are okay! Which is a valid question for the plot, but unrelated to his emotional arc with Asio, or Otus's existence as an actor/character with opinion. So I think giving him a strong opinion about Asio and his behavior at the end of the story by denouncing him or forgiving him or even just saying that he doesn't care anymore because he has his supportive friends, would provide a really striking and gorgeous end for the story and wrap up the themes very nicely.

The reason I'm so stuck on this is because I'm trying to figure out what they're attempting to signify with this ending as it is, and I can't make heads or tails of it. That he only cares about his friends and doesn't even care about Asio? That doesn't make sense, because in its structure, Asio's assertions of Otus's value at the end is given immense importance, and Otus performs no actions indicating indifference. That he can only heal from his trauma now because he did the right thing and got Asio's approval? This is the conclusion I have to reach, and it's not one that I think is healthy or helpful-- in fact, I think this conclusion is in active detriment to the other themes of friendship and found family that were so prevalent in the rest of the game.

All in all, I think Owlboy is a great game that really missed the mark with its ending on the story it was trying to tell.

But the enemy variety is perfect for the length of this game and they don't hold your hand for many of them, which feels very rewarding when you get it straight away thanks to the stellar design.

However, I feel much of the quality takes a rather staggering dip in the second act. The difficulty curve surges, but remains manageable, and the story beats take on a more frenetic pace. There's a sense of urgency from the character dialogue, but no mechanical reason to worry, and you're not really penalized for any of the choices that you make, not a large shocker in a platformer, but still worth mentioning. And, once you unlock the third companion, the difficulty nose dives to trivial. You can spend all your time flapping around like a loser or you can rapidly dash to almost any point on the screen with utter invulnerability while you do so. It's well that he joins the team quite late.
It feels very much like something got cut? The ending feels very nebulous, even with the additional lore from the post-game secrets the final boss feels tacked on and out of the blue. There's a relationship hinted at that the player doesn't experience so it might as well have not happened or it's blown well out of proportion.

Really, it seems like I should have had more time to meet and learn about some of these characters, and, to their credit, I wanted that. I absolutely wanted more and it's completely detrimental to my memory of this game that I didn't get it. There's a whole cast of characters that are introduced after the first massive battle and it felt like I should've spoken to them before? 
This may be symptomatic of a kickstarter game; characters created by contributors that don't have any bearing on the story, but nonetheless have to be featured and I hate it. Again, kudos to the design for seamlessly and naturally integrating individuals that I want to speak to, but my story completionist personality is doing tight, angry somersaults.


Owlboy is suffering from its own success and a disconnect somewhere in the narrative team. I'm not sure if they ran out of time and needed to push it out of the door or if the ending changed drastically at the midnight hour, but while I loved 65% of my time with this game, the ending is an unpalatable, incomplete, and cheap bow slapped on to a game with amazing promise. And doesn't that make it worse? That you were promised the pony on your birthday and you got it between two buns with a side of coleslaw?

Drama aside, do play this game. It's quite short though (I left it on for about a day at work while playing on my breaks, so my time is somewhat inflated) and I'm not a master by any measure so don't be fooled into thinking you missed a lot, it just isn't there.

88855967.review:
[h1]The most imperfect game with an 80-90 Metacritic score I have played in a while[/h1]

[b][u]Visuals and Music[/u][/b]
This game looks and sounds gorgeous. It has some of the best-looking pixel art I’ve seen and great music that makes the whole experience really immersive.
The environments look great but there were still cases after 8 hours of gameplay that I would try to fly through a solid surface because I thought that it was a background. Maybe that’s my fault though.

[b][u]Story[/u][/b]
The story is simple but nice. It has enough depth and twists to keep it interesting but I can’t say that it’s among the best I’ve seen. I could say the same for the characters. Most of them don’t have complicated motivations but they have their own memorable characters. 

[b][u]Gameplay[/u][/b]
This is the weirdest part for me because even though I’d recommend the game, this is where most of its imperfections come from. This game is a very strange mix of different elements that could be seen as an identity crisis. It’s a platformer without much platforming because the main character can fly for 90% of the game. It’s a shooter without very precise controls or satisfying combat mechanics. It’s an RPG in the way it delivers its story and the upgrades you buy. It’s an open world with only 3 main areas to explore and an artificial Metroidvania with no map when it comes to its level design.

Those elements are not necessarily negative. They create an interesting combination that you don’t see often and make it interesting to explore at first. But at the same time, they remain throughout the whole game at a very elementary level. You don’t get to use your skills in new creative ways but only in the most basic and obvious ways that you’d imagine.

The controls of the game work for the most part but they get messy really fast in situations that you have to do things under pressure. I'll provide some examples below.
The only moving character you get to control is Otus. You can carry one of the other characters that can shoot different types of projectiles. Then you can drop them or rotate between them.

Controls example 1: When carrying a character there are times that you need to drop them and pick up something else that’s on the scene. If you happen to drop the character on top of the thing you need to pick up, you’ll end up picking up the character you just dropped once again, and you’d have to drop them further away so they don’t block the object.

Controls example 2: If you try to carry somebody but you’re too close to the ground, this character will appear next to you on the ground and you’ll need to perform an extra action to carry him.  

Controls example 3: When shooting, characters do different things if you press the right trigger once or if you hold it. During some sequences doing one over the other can have serious consequences and well… it happens very often.

Example 4: The jump button is a toggle for flying when airborne. Near the end, there was a sequence where you can fly only for a few seconds and you mostly have to jump. This is the only part of the game that you have to do that and it’s really annoying, not because you’re not used to it but because it’s against the controls. It’s pretty easy to accidentally start flying while you simply wanted to jump. And that part is quite punishing also because you can die by performing 1 wrong jump.

[u]Stealth sequences[/u] are the messiest of them all. You can hide behind objects while walking. But sometimes you have to do the same while flying. Some other times you have to do it while carrying someone and some other times while using your web as a grappling hook. For some enemies, you can easily tell what’s their line of sight but it’s quite harder for others. I think that those sequences don’t add anything to the game. On the contrary, they are designed against the flow of the game but not in a creative way.

What saves the game for me is that all the things that I didn’t like are mitigated by something else. The controls are bad sometimes and I lost because of it, but then there are quite many checkpoints. I could really use a map sometimes but the levels are not so chaotic and the main map is composed of 3 main areas. I hated stealth but in half of the cases, I could get past them by only avoiding a few enemies and then running like a lunatic. 

[b][u]Level Design[/u][/b]
This is partly covered before but I’ll write a few words. The world of the game feels like a real place. There is a variety of areas that look different but I felt that the developers were running out of options on how to make meaningful levels based on the mechanics of the game. There were some nice puzzles and a few interesting gimmicks here and there but the level design never reached a very high standard. I think that it was the definition of decent for most of the time.

[b][u]Summary[/u][/b]
I’ve seen critics giving this game 5/5 and 10/10 and honestly, as much I loved the game myself, I think that’s false advertising. This is the most imperfect game with an 80-90 Metacritic score I have played in a while. It’s a game that tries a lot of things and succeeds in a few.

This is an indie game that’s really important for the industry. It was under development before most gamers were even aware that you can use the word indie and game in the same sentence. It’s a monumental task by a really small team that gave everything they had and for that alone, I would recommend it.

86787207.review:
It is very difficult to give Owlboy the glowing recommendation I wanted to give it. There is so much to like and enjoy, but the enjoyment is harmed by bad design decisions and tedious mechanics. A quick rundown of my opinion on the game for those who don't want my in-depth analysis:

[list]
[*]Wonderful art style
[*]Atmospheric sound and music
[*]Smooth animation
[*]All right story
[*]Characters overreacting is a hit or miss
[*]Tedious mechanics
[*]Awful minigame, which is required for 100% completion
[*]Mortifying cinematic gameplay sections
[/list]

[h1]It is good[/h1]

Owlboy starts out very promising. The small little town of Vellie works well as an establishment to general movement and characters throughout the game. I enjoyed the character interactions that happen in Vellie, and I even had a chuckle or two here and there.

Once the first area had been cleared, I was excited at what might come next. I kept looking forward to the next area, waiting for one amazing, mind blowing level. However, here lies the first misstep in the game in my opinion. The Stratos/Tropos area is just a hub area mostly, but I found myself enjoying the game the most while exploring this mysterious vast space. The game brings forth many ideas, some very good ones like the ability to spawn allies to your grasp, but none of them evolve further from "pick this thing up and put it there". Some of the ideas are even outright horrible, but more on that later.

Without spoiling anything, the story starts out very promising. It has its ups and downs (well, downs for the most part), but I cannot help but feel that some of the story moments are a bit cliché. Take that pirate captain for instance: he is just an evil prick for the sake of being evil. [spoiler]Which is why I thought it was a nice touch by the developers, that you don't actually need to fight him. That would have been boring in my opinion.[/spoiler]

The comedy in this game is really difficult to rate, because it truly is a hit or miss for the most part. Many times characters overreact in a bizarrely manic fashion, which either works or it does not. Sometimes it just came off as the developers trying to be funny, which took me out of the experience. Other times I genuinely laughed, because the whole situation was so ridiculous I could not react in any other way. Character interactions in general are either very good, or not believable. It is a very mixed bag.

The art style is simply majestic. It would seem that the developers really focused on this department the most of their 10-year development, along with general atmosphere. They even decided to put in day/night cycles, which I was not expecting at all. It gives a nice touch to the already fine tuned visuals. Sometimes the whole experience is truly magical, I cannot emphasize how entranced I was while exploring the "hub world" of Tropos/Stratos. It is unfortunate, that some areas are so fleeting; the best areas are not the places you are meant to spend most of your time playing, like the rather large but empty screen right before Advent.

[h1]It is ugly[/h1]

I found it so disappointing, that this game had to have as many problems as it did. As mentioned before, some ideas and mechanics are unnecessarily frustrating to deal with, or simply bad. One rather minor problem that grows into a larger one over the course of the game is the fact, that picking/grabbing objects uses the same key you use to pick up your allies. Countless times I had to move my allies aside, just because they were in the way of me pulling a lever or something. The hassle is what makes it so infuriating, and to me, one of the main reasons for my frustrations with the game.

The cinematic chase sequences are just straight up useless in my opinion. None of them are memorable (to me anyways), and they are a nightmare to get through. It is very difficult to see what is coming ahead of you, because the camera really wants you to see the thing that is chasing you. These moments also highlight the very clunky controls. Sure, they are very flashy, maybe even exciting and epic. But they are so very awful to play. I felt as though moments like these embody all that is wrong with this game. I wonder why the developers went through the hassle of including these in the game, when a straight up boss battle would have been more bearable.

The cannon minigame. Why on earth was this abomination devised in this manner? Mr. Owlboy keeps falling to the ground at ludicrous speed, and you better know the controls from the get go, or you will destroy the poor lad's skull (he keeps falling head first for some reason). Even if you did know the controls, it is absolutely terrible to control Mr. Owlboy. He steers like a tank and must return to his default position very slowly, before you can even think of turning him another direction. If you make ONE mistake, his coconut gets cracked. This one minigame wasted many hours of my playtime, that I could have spent more wisely elsewhere. I regret ever playing it.

The worst to last, the entire jungle stage. The whole gimmick of this level is that the jungle cave is very dark, so you cannot see without a light source. It would not be such an issue, if there was a competent light source available [b]at all times[/b]. The only thing you have available always, is one of your allies' gun that shoots a tiny flame while reloading the weapon. The flame is so tiny, it does not even light up your characters. Later on it gets better with light fruits and whatnot, but the entire stage is introduced with that useless flame that helps nobody. This stage almost made me quit the game single-handedly, because I was so frustrated with the dark corridors with no competent light source in sight. I am glad I persevered, because the final moments with the game are very good in my opinion.

[h1]Final thoughts[/h1]

Owlboy is a difficult game to recommend. On one hand, it gives such an invigorating adventure with beautiful visuals, music, sounds, even the story is very good sometimes. But on the other, it was clearly made visuals first: the game feels very clunky, some design decisions are questionable or bad, it is buggy on occasion, and they actually made the cannon minigame into a reality, the mad people. It is incredible, how this game is so polished on one side, and so unpolished on the other. I will give it a recommendation purely on the opinion, that I enjoyed my time so thoroughly in Stratos/Tropos, and because the final area and ending is actually epic, not just visually. Do keep in mind, however, that what I have mentioned previously may not fit someone else's idea of fun and enjoyment.

7/10

[b]My playtime:[/b] 12.2h (based on Steam, 100% achievement)
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] No.
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (12 achievements).
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] No.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
[b]Owlboy[/b] takes on an interesting approach by featuring a flying character in a platformer game. The game sets on a planet where flying is required to reach most places. You'll explore a lot of areas, seeing breathtaking visuals as you flap your wings.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- ~7 unique boss fights
- Plenty of checkpoints to make the game easier
- Secret places for collectibles for those who like to explore

[b]Cons:[/b]
- Clunky controls
- Some areas are too dark to explore

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]Yes.[/b]
[i]If you like to play platformer games with high detailed pixel art, buy this game when it's heavily discounted.[/i]

[hr][/hr]
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
[b]Owlboy[/b] surprises me with its stunning visuals. The high detailed pixel art reminds me of [b]Metal Slug[/b], especially with the use of [url=https://2dwillneverdie.com/tutorial/give-your-sprites-depth-with-sub-pixel-animation/]sub-pixel animation[/url], an animation technique to move some colors in a sprite to simulate movement. Animations are the core of [b]Owlboy[/b]; every scene feels lively with how everything moves outside - the characters, the clouds - even the grasses are moving. While the exteriors are filled with animations, interiors are filled with detailed backgrounds instead, making you fully immersed in the game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2385843709 

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story in [b]Owlboy[/b] is brief despite it holding a lot of meaning. Most dialogues are simple and easy to follow with your best friend commenting about what is happening to both of you. However, it makes the story empty sometimes since you have to fill the important parts yourself. Some events also feel a bit rushed, especially with the introduction of villains. It took me a while before I can fully grasp the story because of this.

Despite the straightforward story, the game doesn't fail in its worldbuilding. Detailed pieces of information are left hidden in several places and you must piece the story together to know what happened. The extra story only serves as additional information, but it's still an interesting read.

[h1]The Game[/h1]
[b]Gameplay[/b]
Platformer games are usually denoted by the use of platforms to reach other places, but it doesn't seem to be the case in [b]Owlboy[/b]. The flying mechanic makes the grounds feel useless, especially when the area features open spaces. There are some cases where the game disables your flying ability and forces you to either use your jumping or companion skills, but when you do, the control doesn't seem to cooperate since it's hard to switch between flying and jumping. Heck, it took me a while to realize that I can also jump.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2385843743 

[b]Stealth[/b]
Stealth areas are plenty but felt useless. The game offers some sort of warning at first where you have to clear an area without being seen. However, the warning seems to be gone as time goes and you have to figure out the stealth areas yourself. While this might work okay since most stealth areas have similar enemies, it's hard to figure out what you're supposed to do to clear the area without being seen most of the time. Surprisingly, you can clear the area faster by rushing your way through the exit, beating the purpose of a stealth mechanic in the first place.

[b]Combat[/b]
The idea to implement different characters to clear different obstacles is clever, although it's ruined with its controls. Three companions will be available as you progress the game, each with its pros and cons, which can be summoned and carried whenever you like. However, having three companions that you have to cycle through to summon makes it hard to summon the ones that you want - I spent most of my time in boss fights just for this.

It wasn't easy to figure out how to defeat all bosses since you need to notice the safe spots from their attacks - some bosses will do an attack that almost occupies the whole screen for you to avoid. It took me several tries to beat all bosses due to their difficulty, but it felt satisfying to beat them. Some bosses feel unfair though, especially one particular boss where you must defeat it without taking damage.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2385843769 

[b]Length and Difficulty[/b]
I finished [b]Owlboy[/b] in 11.7h and continued playing to check the secrets that I missed. The game feels more like a bullet hell at first, especially with the game featuring a flying character and a party member that can shoot bullets. It shows more of its platforming elements later on, despite the empty map. Although there hardly any health-restoring items, checkpoints are abundant and you'll always respawn at full health. It turns the difficulty down a lot while giving more challenge to those who want to try no death run at the same time.

[b]Problems[/b]
Most problems that I had with this game are due to the clunky controls. The game revolves around grabbing your companions before you can use their ability and it's hard to do it when you're standing on the ground. This affects greatly on boss fights, especially since it takes longer than your invincibility frame to last before you're ready to fight. Moreover, the game uses the left mouse button and hold the left mouse button to trigger different attacks - it was hard not to mix up both.

[h1]Specs[/h1]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
This game is a mixed bag to me. Most of my enjoyment comes from enjoying the beautiful-looking scenery. Exploration feels empty since it's easy to avoid enemies by flying while areas that don't allow you to fly has nothing in it, encouraging you to dash through them to clear the area faster. The clunky controls also hindering me to enjoy the game to its fullest. However, despite all that, it is still a good game, although I'm not sure if I can recommend it if it's not heavily discounted.

83753905.review:
Owlboy is a side scrolling adventure that was almost decade in the making, so let's take a look at it.

Story:

You play as Otus, who is a mute owl man living in a village in the sky. Otus is often made fun of by the village because he's clumsy and accident prone, with his only friend being Geddy, a human guard of the village. After Sky Pirates attack the village you set out on a quest to stop them and learn about the history of the Owls.

While the story of the game isn't incredibly deep, it's really well written. It has charm and every character is unique in their own ways. You meet interesting characters along the way to whom you really start getting attached to, not to mention the incredibly emotional story segments that cut you deep. 

Graphics:

Owlboy's pixel art style is absolutely jaw dropping. The game looks absolutely stunning and I literally cannot praise the art style enough. Each environment you visit is bright and colorful and you visit a lot of places, each with their unique looks, it's honestly quite impressive how detailed every little thing is.

Every character is different and has their own unique set of animations. The details of this game are absolutely insane to say the least. 

Audio:

The audio design is also really good. The music is top notch and there's plenty of music tracks to match the tone of the area you're in. Quiet atmospheric tracks when it's set during the night, intense ambience when you're in enemy locations and so on and forth. 

The sound effects are decent, albeit nothing incredibly special. They work with what they set out to do and I found a few of the audio effects incredibly satisfying especially the wooshing noises the characters make. Even the dialogue scrolling noise which is something I find most games tend to mess up, was very light on the ears and I have to give it props.

Gameplay:

Owlboy is a side scrolling adventure where as Otus, you will platform, solve puzzles and fight enemies. Otus is not a fighter and often you will have to pick up items to throw them at enemies to defeat. However as Otus you can carry around your friends to help you solve puzzles and fight enemies. For example Geddy can be picked and he can use his gun to attack enemies. 

You control the aiming yourself and it works fine for the most part, but it's never ideal. It feels quite finnicky at first and requires sometime to get used to, but I quickly picked up on it and I did end up liking the combat quite a bit. 

As Otus you can fly around and reach areas and that allows you to cover a lot of land. It's quite fun to fly around and look for secrets and explore areas to interact with the village people and other items. It's a very light metroidvania, because there's multiple ways to go, but often then not there's not many places to visit which allows you to cover more land in faster time. 

There is puzzles for you to solve every so often, but they are often really easy, only a handful of puzzles might make you stop in your tracks to think, but that's a rare instance, but they serve as a nice little pallet cleanser. So now let's also talk about the boss fights. They are often intense and often more difficult than anything else in the game. They are often the only places where you might die. 

Verdict:

Often when games spend a lifetime in development, people think they will end up being bad, but Owlboy shows that is not the case in every instance. It's a brilliant game that is visually stunning, fun to play and has a really great story with plenty of funny and emotional moments to grip you. This is an absolutely amazing game worth your time.

Final Rating:
10/10

Pros:
+ Visuals are absolutely stunning
+ Emotional story
+ Great characters
+ Fun Gameplay
+ Great music 

Cons:
N/A

78509065.review:
Owlboy is a pixellated adventure game.  Beat it and 100%'d everything in roughly 15 hours (12 hours and 3 on the one minigame), using a game controller for everything but the minigame, where I switched to keyboard.  Difficulty is Moderate to a little hard (minigame has an absurd difficulty curve and is very hard).  

- The soundtrack is amazing.  One of the most inspired, active soundtracks I've heard in a long while.

- The story starts out sad, almost depressing, but gets better until a whopper of an ending.  

- Layout and levels are tight.  The world doesn't feel big at all and there's lots of hidden places to find and explore within it.  Each level is unique, though there isn't much variety in enemies between them. Instead of keeping the camera centered on the character, the camera moves from room to room.  This leads to enemies being out of sight one path over, then the camera swinging to show them out of nowhere when you enter the next area and you getting hit randomly (Or their projectile comes at you from off camera).  Other gamers had an issue with this, but it didn't get in the way whatsoever during my playthrough. 

- The bosses are all different and memorable.  Their difficulty varied.

- The controls are...  Okay?  Aiming was a bit of a pain (accursed flying swarms).  My joystick was extra sensitive to some inputs like jump-gliding at the last level and I had to use the D-pad instead.  Minigame is, well, I'll get to that...  Flying around, swapping between helpers, dashing about, and shooting in general wasn't that hard to figure out, though I did continually teleport a friend into my grip instead of grab fruit from trees throughout the playthrough.

- Most achievements are attainable easily on the first playthrough.  Choice others, like hitting your friend X times, seem arbitrary and a chore.  

- The cannon minigame is about as fun as a nail in the boot.  You need to do it to get 100% of the coins.  Its controls are foreign from the rest of the game (I had to swap to keyboard because my controller wasn't very responsive to them), it's intolerably fast, and unlike the rest of the game the difficulty curve is insanely drastic.  Another issue is there is no quick-start option for it; if you die, which you will, repeatedly, every 10 seconds for over 30 minutes until your reflexes get in order, you have to jump back up to the cannon and hit the mouse button to re-initiate the launch sequence animation.  At some point it stopped being fun.  Which is a shame.  I did have fun playing, in a masochistic sort of way, but making it mandatory to 100% the coins seems cruel.   The only good part about the mini game is the course is short.  

-*** Epilepsy warning!  Do not play this game if you have epilepsy.  Blinky blink blink blink blink flash boom white trigger lights ahoy! 

-*  (Lite) Motion Sickness Warning!  On top of the constant strobing light show, the screen will shake.  A lot.  Like you're playing on an excited washing machine.  Never the less, I had no issues playing right up until the end of it, where I got a miserable headache.  And a short break with water fixed that.  So if you get motion sickness from games, you'll probably be fine if you take breaks now and then. 




Would I recommend Owlboy?  Oh yeah, sure.  It's a fun, cute game with a fascinating plot and gripping music.   It's fun trying to 100% everything on the first play through.  The game is by no means perfect, and I could see the one mini game royally turning people off, but you can still beat the game without it.  Owlboy is a game that deserves at least one playthrough and some fan art on the side.

I'm of two minds with this game. The game is beautiful - easily one of the best-looking examples of pixel art in modern gaming. It's also decently fun, with secrets to discover, boss fights to win, and new abilities to unlock.

The game, however, lacks a certain amount of polish - not in the graphics, but in how it plays. It's not a whole lot of fun to have your tense boss fight interrupted by having to click through dialogue in the middle of it (with control taken away from you and, when returned without a lot of indicators that it's back, you have to scramble). There are sections of platforming-type puzzles that were a bit of a chore and a bore to get through - and it felt a little like they were put in to serve the story, which was fairly mediocre and frankly seemed to get in the way of the game. The controls in the last part, where you have some difficult platform maneuvers, felt unresponsive. 

 I finished it, which is a high compliment in my book - I have no trouble dropping terrible, boring games if they're not finished...so it's not awful. I don't want the slick graphics to give potential buyers the idea that the game is better than it is, though, and so I'm giving this a thumbs-down. It's fun, but there are many other platformers (e.g., Braid, Aquaria, Mark of the Ninja, Fez) that are a lot better. If you don't have any of those, hold off on Owlboy until you do and return to this one once you've exhausted other, better options.

This is yet another 2D retro pixel platformer, one of literally thousands.   There's a few gimmicks here, like you can fly, and the production values, despite being a retro pixel game, are slightly better than most of these games.  Control a mutated owl/human hybrid creature and fly around the place killing bosses and clicking through pointless dialogues.

On the technical side of things, retro pixel graphics have been used instead of contemporary PC graphics, despite the game being released in 2016.  This makes the game look pretty ugly, and given how much work seems to have gone into it, it's not really an excuse to say they made the game look bad, but on purpose.   That aside, many elements of the game are lacking polish, for example, they use discrete screens despite this being on PC and there being no need to do that.  The transition between screens is a rapid scrolling action that causes nausea, in no small part because the resolution is so low in the game (on purpose again). 

This might be acceptable for a $1.50 or a $3 game, but they're charging an eye watering $34.99 for this, full AAA pricing, for retro pixel shovelware.  That's up against games like DooM Eternal, the Halo collection, well, pretty much anything on Steam.   It's just incomprehensible they think any retro pixel junk is worth that kind of money.
