72793459.review:
Owlboy is an ambitious and stunning little indie gem. It's obvious from the start that it is a product of love. The pixel art is vibrant and detailed, and the multi-layered foregrounds and backgrounds make the world feel more visually alive than most games of its style. Characters have charming, unique designs and are given expressive animations to fit them. The music is beautifully composed, performed, and timed within the game. As far as style goes, Owlboy is a masterpiece.

It isn't lacking in substance either. The story is a simple enough adventure with an interesting but fairly predictable twist yet an incredibly charming world and characters. There's also a clear understanding of what makes an adventure feel grand. Between dungeons and dramatic setpieces there are moments of respite wherein the characters simply relax, reflect, and bond. Just as well there are moments of anger and quiet sadness. Moments such as these are more important to a compelling adventure than action and heroics; Owlboy shows a clear understanding of this. What it lacks in deeper narrative it more than makes up for in execution.

If the gameplay had held up to the same standards as the above I may have considered it a masterpiece. Unfortunately this is where my complaints start.

Owlboy's biggest strength may also be its biggest shortcoming. The beautifully detailed art often makes Otus hard to see. Part of the problem is Otus is brown which in of itself is not a color that stands out. Add to this that many locations are portrayed in shades of brown, with brown enemies, and brown projectiles. These problems aren't always happening at once but overall it seems in making the game so incredible to look at D-Pad Studio forgot that visual language is important for gameplay as well as atmosphere. The color of a character and its environment or enemies don't always have to be completely contrasted, of course, but this game struggles to find a balance. The issue is worsened when the companions you carry distract from Otus even more with their own distinct visuals. In the end I felt through the entire game that I never had a complete grasp on Otus' hitbox and often left combat feeling somewhat frustrated. Add to this that the reticle is very slippery and that Otus seems slow to react at times. Ultimately only a handful of combat encounters, unsurprisingly those with fairly neutral backgrounds and one distinct enemy, were fulfilling. However, the scripted action setpieces were thrilling and never overstayed their welcome.

The puzzling and platforming were at least fun, overall. Even the dreaded cannon minigame only bothered me in that you had to fly to a platform and watch a short cutscene to restart, which you will be doing many times.

If I had one more complaint it would be that if you're going to incentivize collecting everything you should perhaps have a limited fast travel system and a rough map. I never got lost myself, but it would be nice to have a frame of reference when deciding to re-examine the world at end game. By that point I couldn't be bothered to fly through the entire map once more looking for every last obscure coin.

All this isn't to say the gameplay is bad, it's just the weakest aspect of the game and I wanted to elaborate a bit more on the problems with it for those seeking a polished gameplay experience. That said, it's functional enough that I was never too frustrated to see what the characters would encounter next and in a game like this that may be all that matters. It was enough that I would still recommend this game for the experience alone; it's not a game I will soon forget. For every flaw in the mechanics, every encounter that I couldn't find clarity in, I found myself excited for the next dialogue between the characters. I wanted to hear more of the soundtrack and see it set against the stunning art direction in whatever new location that team Otus would find themselves in next. Despite everything I've criticized, I never once considered dropping the game. In the end its strengths outshine its weaknesses.

Owlboy is a platformer in which you play as Otus, a mute, adorable little owl-boy who lives his life in a little village on a floating island in the sky, getting lessons (and abuse) from his teacher and hanging out with his best friend Geddy. But soon this life is disrupted as a group of sky pirates attack the village, stealing an ancient relic that was created by the ancient owls. It is up to Otus and Geddy to head out and save the world... if they're not distracted by just how gorgeous the world is.

Okay, calling the game a platformer might be a tad generous, but calling it a flight simulator isn't really accurate either. Because Otus can fly all over the place there's very little actual platforming, and the gameplay instead consists more of flying through various tunnels and avoiding obstacles. Adding to this there are some fight segments, where you basically fly circles around the enemies and pepper them with bullets... aside from a few bosses where you are instead kicked around like a feathery football, because they have attacks that are almost impossible to dodge. And then there are parts where you have to be stealthy, or else you risk getting eaten in a surprisingly graphic manner which reminded me of some of the deaths in Heart of Darkness. Adding to that there are some minor metroidvania-elements, but because the game is overall very linear I mostly mention this for completeness sake.

Owlboy could easily be mistaken for a good game to have your kid play before they can start on more advanced games, but don't be fooled; this game is far from easy. It's not particularly difficult either, but there are parts that really surprised me with just how difficult they were, mostly the aforementioned bosses and the very first stealth section you encounter. I think the best way to describe the difficulty would be "inconsistent". There are segments where you have to activate a timed switch, then fly through the gate it opened with only a two-second margin, and as I mentioned some of the bosses have attacks that are so difficult to dodge that my best strategy was to just hope I could tank through them. Meanwhile, the very last boss of the game (who is powered up by these super-powerful relics which could very well end the world, I'll remind you) got handed an ass whooping on my very first try. This is not to say that the gameplay is bad, it's smooth, it's occasionally satisfying, and it works well enough to take you through the game, but there are certain speed-bumps on the way, if you catch my drift.

The story of Owlboy is fine. Not great, but it does what it can with a standard setup. Outcast must step up to the challenge, prove his worth, find the macguffins, and save the world, that sort of thing. What makes it work is not the story in itself (mostly because the ending is kind of disappointing, like they ran out of time when putting it together), but rather the characters. You've got Otus, of course, the mute with low self-esteem but a surprising lot of bravery, you've got Geddy, the best friend who sticks with you through thick and thin even though he's kind of a coward, and later on you recruit two other characters who, without wishing to spoil, are also surprisingly fleshed-out, considering the small amount of time we spend with them (the game isn't that long). Too bad the same can't be said for the villain, who basically spends all of his time just stomping around and acting evil for the sake of being evil. It's kind of a shame too, I was hoping there would be SOMETHING more to him than a mean attitude and a frowny face.

So the gameplay and the story are servicable, but nothing that you can't find elsewhere. However, if there is one thing that will sell you on this game, it is the graphics. Now, I normally do not care for graphics, as long as I can make out what is going on I'm good, I'm more focused on the gameplay, that sort of thing. But Owlboy is one of those rare examples where I can sicerely recommend giving it a look based on graphics alone. Seriously, this game is gorgeous! I would buy printed maps from the game and hang in my living room if I could! And I know some people will say "well, it's a pixel-2D game, those are easier to make look good than 3D games". But to that I say, it may indeed be easy to make a game in pixel-2D. Making a game look GOOD in pixel-2D, on the other hand, is difficult. Especially when you are shooting for the kind of vibrant colors that Owlboy uses, and smooth animations. And I will never get tired of Otus's surprised-face. That is a face which says "I have stared into the abyss, before I realized it didn't have any underpants."

Oh, and the music is nice too.

Overall, I had a fine time with Owlboy. It's not a very long game, it took me 6 hours to go from start to finish with some minor side-stuff. But if you're looking for a well done 2D game with decent gameplay, lovable characters, good music and marvelous graphics, you should give Owlboy a look. Recommended.

62727236.review:
The problem is that the game misses the point about why retro platformers felt so great to play. It was that the core sensation of moving through the world was itself satisfying — whether the momentum of running down a slope, the sensation of travel (and peril) when jumping from one moving platform to the next, or the satisfying springyness of a well judged bounce off an enemy's head. In a good platform game, all of these actions deliver tangible feedback to the player, which gives them a feel for the physics of the world, and a sense of agency over their avatar.

There are many indie platformers which understand this, and successfully recapture that magic, but Owlboy doesn't.

In Owlboy, the flying mechanics amount to the following: Press Jump, press Jump again in the air. That's it. You're flying now. Suspended in the air, Owlboy waits patiently for the next movement impulse, which is to say pressing the analogue stick in 1 of 8 directions. Owlboy will then move in a straight, perfect and unfaltering line in that direction, at a constant speed. No acceleration, no momentum, no resistance. No dip or swoop as you beat your wings against the imagined wind. I'm not trying to exaggerate or be comically harsh when I say there is a stronger and more nuanced sensation of movement when we're sending Pacman around corners of a maze — there just is. In a game that is all about flight, it's a missed opportunity. 

The foundation of Owlboy is therefore not original or satisfying platform game mechanics, which were then embellished with beautiful art. The foundation instead seems to be that some skilled artists knew they could create highly detailed, painstaking pixel art vistas, and then later had to conceive of a game which might fit into them. Visually impressive, but not fun to play.

55856439.review:
[h1] Abstract [/h1]
Owlboy is a charming little indie game with a simple but elegant control scheme, a lovely soundtrack, beautiful pixel art, and a rich world lore which the story provides a lens into.
[b] Overall Score 7/10. Worth playing but not likely to change your life. [/b]

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]
Owlboy presents a unique gameplay style, with the ability to freely fly through the 2D world the focus is less upon platforming or even precision flying but instead allowing the challenges to be about the combat system and puzzle solving. the flying itself feels good with the ability to dodge in midair providing an elevated sense of control as well as allowing for quick traversal throughout already completed areas, combat relies heavily upon use of companions rather than the inherit abilities of the main character. However thanks to the ease with which you can switch between and control those companions it never feels like a detriment. The only real issue occurs with the fact that your first companion is made largely irrelevant by the final companion. Otherwise the mechanical gameplay is solid and leaves very to complain about
[b] Gameplay Score 8/10 [/b]

[h1] Sound Design [/h1]
One of the twin pillars holding up this game and explaining its high rating. The sound design is just absolutely glorious, it successfully sets the tone throughout the game and manages the not to be underestimated feat of not becoming bland over time. furthermore the little sounds that sprinkle flavor through the game are simple and elegant in a way that complements the score around it without ever distracting from it.
[b] Sound Design Score 10/10 [/b]

[h1] Art Design [/h1]
The other pillar of this game. The pixel art on display here is masterful. The retro style often used as a crutch to reduce the time and costs of art design is instead elevated to an unprecedented standard with multiple layers of foreground and background being merged together to create a visually dynamic world that is constantly impressive. Furthermore the animations are masterful with real emotion and weight on display even in small motions. The Intro alone reveals the amount of work that went in to making these characters move in a way that lets you feel for them, and sets a gold standard within the style. 
[b] Art Design Score 10/10 [/b]

[h1] Story [/h1]
This area is sadly the weakest part of the game by a wide margin. To begin the length of the game is sadly lacking. Short games are fine in general and can even provide experiences that are wasted on a longer format, but this is not on of them. With the way that the game plays and how the narrative moves forward the point where you enter the final section feels like it should be at most the halfway point. in this case specifically the atmosphere of the world cries out for much more exploration and depth. Whats more the story being told here does not do justice to the world it is being presented in. many details are revealed hastily and given no time to sink in or even be processed by the characters before the next major plot point steamrolls into place and barrels the game closer to the end. The other failing lies in that much of the dialogue feels like it needs a few more passes and to be read aloud and adjusted before being presented. In fact the lack of voice acting is in this case a good thing as much of what the characters say is stilted and awkward in ways that do not mesh with the character delivering them. It is truly disappointing as it is clear that the bones of a rich and truly epic story are here but not given the room to be fully explored. Also it should be noted that this issue is exacerbated by the notable lack of side content within the game. despite a large focus on completionist style treasure hunting on display in the achievements there is no real reason for doing most of it within the narrative of the game. 
[b] Story Score 4/10 [/b]

[h1] Final Thoughts [/h1]
In the end and despite what flaws the game has I do still recommend this game fairly highly on its merits alone. the only final issue i wish to address is a slight caveat to my recommendation. This game is one that most people should play, if they can get a good price for it. As it stands the game retails for $25 with a $10 soundtrack which if bundled together costs $31.50. As the soundtrack is lovely I would be remiss to recommend the game without it. The problem lies with the fact that in for the length of the game the price is fairly steep, if you truly loves games of this genre and want to show your full support for the devs then that that price is worth it, but if this game being for you is a question even at all i would recommend looking for a sale before acquiring it.

55725554.review:
It's a solid experience that leaves you wanting more, albeit not necessarily in a good way.

Gameplay is relatively simple, but fun. You've got  jumping, flying, spinning, dashing, and attacking. There are occasional twists on movement as well as a couple hidden features and interactions to make things interesting, but as a whole, the controls and how you use them don't really change. Characters are almost all decently written, I ended up surprised at the amount of depth Geddy and Asio had in particular. The music is outright great, it's a fun combination of chiptune and orchestral mixes and they pretty much all sound amazing; while I do plan on getting into this game's (many) shortfalls soon, there's pretty much nothing negative to say about the soundtrack. The art is also amazing from start to finish. The style stays consistently beautiful and charming, and I really can't think of any glaring errors or moments at all where I didn't feel enthralled by the game's looks. The plot is also decently written for what it is. It's starts off whimsical enough before delving into some really dark depths with some very high stakes, although it does somewhat fizzle out by the end.

The best criticism I could give this game would be that there was room for more.

SPOILERS PAST HERE

There was room for more boss fights, we get like three or maybe four and that's it. Movement and combat in this game is relatively fun and even a little tactical, and it would've been nice to have seen the limits of the system in place really pushed and tested, but they're not. You've got Geddy the weak but long-range shooter, although even with his upgrade he never really gains that much range. Alphonse has a powerful but short/med-range attack with a long reload time, and actually functions perfectly in his niche. Twig is meant to be a stunner, but in most situations his attacks take enemies out anyway, and what's more he has a full-screen range and a very fast fire time, essentially making Geddy borderline obsolete. This isn't helped by the fact that there isn't much incentive to actually kill most of the enemies you encounter. There's a few areas where you get coins for clearing them out once, but afterwords there's no reason to not just bind enemies with Twig and run.

There was room for more areas and world building. We get Vellie, Advent (but not really), The Owl Temple, The Owl Tower, The Floating Continent, and a few caves. That's pretty much it. You never actually explore Advent, and nobody in Vellie talks about any town other than Advent, which makes the world seem weirdly tiny. There's no discussion of other islands, continents, or kingdoms, the inhabited world just seems to consist of the 10 or so people who live in Vellie and Advent (and the three stragglers in other lands). The owls have it even worse off. We're told that there aren't many of them, but if the remaining owls really just consist of the 6 males we encounter, they're basically near-extinct, and no one acknowledges it. Twig comes from a race of talking stick bugs, and given his dialogue there's seemingly a race of talking man-sized spiders as well, but neither are addressed. Are Twig and his family the only talking stick bugs alive? Are there more races of sapient beings on other floating islands? We never find out. More areas are definitely needed, but more than that what was needed was even the mention of more of the world in general.

There was room for more rewards. The cloak upgrade we get is extremely fun to use, but by the time we get it it's borderline useless. What's worse is that power-wise it's sits at this point where it's blatantly an endgame item and you understand why you get it so late, and yet there could've easily been cloaks that fit in-between the starter cloak and the final one. Geddy's upgrade is, well, borderline useless. The gun is still weak, and the scope doesn't really add much range at all to compensate. He easily could've used another range upgrade of even a minor power upgrade. Alphonse, again, is pretty much the only character that's perfectly balanced. His one upgrade gives him a tremendous about of range without really shifting his role as the slow, but powerful shooter. Even better range or faster firing speed in exchanged for slightly weaker attacks could've been other upgrades along his path though. Twig has no upgrades, although given how useful he already is he more or less didn't need any. Honestly his range and stun time could've been nerfed somewhat while still keeping him incredibly useful, and allowed for some space for upgrades for him as well. Going back to the more areas suggestion, having more enemies and a greater variety of them would've allowed for more room for combat oriented upgrades in turn, and would've allowed the developers to further develop and differentiate our three companions playstyles and even our own, but unfortunately that's another area where the game simply falls short.

Finally, there was room for more plot and character development. If Noctae could predict his death and Otus's eventual role, why didn't he leave more messages? The reveal in The Sanctum might've had more impact if he had spoken to us more than once, perhaps through recordings left in other temples and ruins. Solus should've had more appearances, and his connection to older Owl lore should've been expanded upon. We see him so little and he talks so little about Owl history that the fact that he was apparently the most knowledgeable about it kind of came out of left field. I guess we were maybe supposed to assume that the scrolls he was dropping everywhere were important old documents? It would've helped the plot a lot if he had actually interacted with Otus more over the course of the game. He could've easily had a permanent spot in Vellie or the surrounding areas where we could've optionally chatted to him about the Owl Temple and the Lost Continent, and he could've provided background information on both areas, showing us his knowledge and allowing the player to form a greater connection with him as well. More unique Pirates and just more development for the pirates in general would've been nice. Alphonse says he aspires to be an actor, but there's never a point where we see him act. No scene where he uses his skill to stealthily trick his way around fellow pirates, and no scene where he tries to orate for the other crew members around a campfire, it's just a throwaway line. Dirk claimed to feel a genuine sense of camraderie with Alphonse, but that never shows through their interactions. He doesn't seem any more jovial or kind with Alphonse when they're alone than he does at any other point in the game. Molstrom is a war bot obsessed with destruction, but even he should've been aware that having all of the islands fly into space would've ended all life and consequently made any further attempts to wage war impossible. He's seemingly just mindlessly evil for no real reason. On a more minor note, Geddy's potential relationship with Mandolin is sort of mentioned in her diary, but otherwise never brought up or addressed properly in the game at all. Geddy doesn't even interact with Mandolin more than once in the beginning of the game, and never mentions her at all beyond that, which is insane considering Mandolin's last diary entry mentions them discussing moving in together. You'd think that'd make for a good fireside chat, but nope.

END SPOILERS

Overall, despite the long development cycle, Owlboy comes off feeling like it could've used even more time. The music and art are clearly where most of the love went, and it shows, at the unfortunate detriment to the world and plot. This is certainly worth a pickup at a discount, but don't be surprised if you end the game feeling somewhat unfulfilled.

If I were to describe Owlboy in one word, it would be "Mesmerizing."

This game is such a perfect example to all gamers and developers out there that if they have a dream, a story they want to tell through a video game, they should take the plunge. The developers on Owlboy have been working on this game for roughly 10 years, and the end product is absolutely stunning. Beautiful pixel art, fitting and emotional music, and lively, vivid characters.

However, all that glitters is not gold. Owlboy, although having it's many great attributes as mentioned, contains several flaws, and it truly pains me to say that considering the amount of work and love put into this game.

It's very evident that the devs put priority in the art and music in this game. The sprites are all so beautifully animated, and detailed. So are the landscapes and backgrounds. And the music finds itself in the same area. Perfectly orchestrated, and fitting for every scenario. However, the developers put these two in such high priority, that I feel they neglected the most important part when making a game; The Gameplay.

I believe Owlboy would've benefited greatly from one more year in development, but that year being dedicated to adding more fun gameplay mechanics. More upgrades, more levels, more abilities, and maybe even more party members. Although this game has been in development for as long as it has, I feel like they spent most, if not all of that time developing the art and music.

It also pains me just how short this game is. It's only roughly 6 hours long. It's truly disappointing because of just how interesting and pretty the world of Owlboy is. I would've loved to be captivated in it's world for longer, but before I knew it, the game was already coming to a close. I hope a DLC is released with more Owlboy lore, for I deeply enjoy this universe that has been created.

All of that being said, I still cannot say you should skip Owlboy. It still remains as one of the greatest Indie experiences I have played here on Steam. And for that, pick up this game when you have a chance.

I give Owlboy:

8.2 Grown Man Tears out of 10

By the way, play this game with a controller, it is far more enjoyable than with a mouse and keyboard.

I'm a big fan of 2D platformers and pixel art, but sadly Owlboy doesn't deliver much apart from the gorgeous art. It lacks a strong direction and doesn't really know what it wants to be. It feels like in the end they just wanted to play it super safe and appealed to the lowest common denominator.

[b]It's an indie platformer that feels like a bad AAA "movie game" where the already mediocre gameplay is interrupted by endless cutscenes with trite dialog every 30 seconds.[/b]

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]
It's not even a true platformer, much less a metroidvania. The gameplay style is all over the place. You can fly and move in any direction, so sometimes it's a twin stick shooter, sometimes almost a shmup (shoot 'em up). The other times it tries to be a puzzle game where you complete super obvious puzzles by putting things into slots. Then sometimes it also wants to be a stealth game. There's a lot of stealth sections and they're as boring as can be. You just hide in the bushes, wait for the guard to look the other way, move to the next bush, rinse and repeat. Practically any one of these playstyles is nothing but tedium because there's no difficulty. You can beat the final boss on your first try because you can just i-frame dodge non-stop.

While the game does have a continuous world, there's little exploration to be done because all progress is gated by story events. You can revisit earlier areas to collect more coins that unlock marginal upgrades (+health, some cosmetics (that disappear after 1 hit!), some minor damage boosts) and that's the extent of the game's metroidvania elements.

[h1]Story:[/h1]
Aesthetics and themes wise, Owlboy tries to be Zelda, Disney and Ghibli all at once. But story wise what we're left with is an extremely tired and cliche "collect 3 macguffins before the big bad does" plot. And this objective will be talked about in every other cutscene, in case you forget about it.  And oh boy, there's tons of those, every time you walk through a door the game does a slow panning shot and the characters start blabbering about how scared they are that the big bad might find the macguffin before them.

To be fair, there's an interesting subplot about an ancient civilization playing god, but it's never expanded upon. In fact, the game just ends abruptly without ever explaining anything properly. They don't even tell you if the main character [spoiler]lives or dies[/spoiler].

[h1]In Short:[/h1]
Owlboy is a mediocre puzzle platformer that feels more like a bad interactive movie. It's only about 8 hours long and there's no replayability. The pixel art and orchestral soundtrack are definitely the highlights. Otherwise, nobody would be talking about this game at all.

Other than the plot, which is golden, the music in Owlboy is unbelievably good. Like, you won't believe how good it is until you've heard it yourself in-game. Think Undertale-levels of music fitting the story. Yeah, I know what I wrote. The art is amazing as well, and keeps getting better as the game progresses, which was a delightful surprise. Given all the above, I very much recommend Owlboy.
This is not to say that it isn't without faults, however. For one thing, the writing can feel child-like and simplistic at times, with characters sometimes speaking in ways I feel is subtly "off" (I can't pin down what exactly, but it's there). The combat sections, while mildly fun, aren't anything impressive either, and a few of the boss fights introduced confusing gimmicks I had to look up to solve. For the most part the puzzles were fun and satisfying, bordering on easy.
So Owlboy does have flaws. Some things could have been done better, but honestly, at the end of the day, I hardly care. The overall experience of Owlboy was a magical one, and I feel privileged to have experienced the world its creators made. This game will live on inside me for a long time to come...

The only objective that the main character Otus has, is to prove to his idiot mentor that he isn't useless and incompetent; yet, in the final moments of the game, that is exactly how I feel: useless and incompetent. The art and sound design is superb. I don't have much else to add there. If you appreciate those aspects of a game, then this might be a worthwhile purchase for you.

50269209.review:
[b][i]Owlboy is a charming, gorgeously illustrated story. It is a tale about finding and holding on to courage, comfort, camaderie and resolution amidst chaos, amidst problems that are seemingly beyond one's own control.[/i][/b]

Yes, it is a [i]story-focused[/i] game. Whilst there is a fair amount of (fun!) platforming/puzzle-solving, Owlboy wants you to get familiar with Otus, Geddy, the quaint village of Vellie, how the Floating Continents came to be. Rest assured, there's no excessive dialogue or 'lore-dumping' here! I won't deny there's a bit of world-building to keep up with -- but with good pacing, clear visuals and expressive character interactions, the game makes it really easy to understand what's going on. D-Pad Studio gradually conveys the world of Owlboy and its inhabitants in a 'Show, not Tell' manner, a form of storytelling even someone like me (...and I'm not much of a reader!) can appreciate.

Here's an example: one of the concepts that Owlboy explores is the discrimination of the disabled -- right when you start the game, you are introduced to the protagonist Otus, a mute young owl struggling in a backdrop of his own nightmares. You are forced to literally walk him through a litany of demoralizing and snide comments. In character interactions, Otus often expresses angry and happy faces to answer Yes/No prompts. Otus outwardly shows feelings of sadness, of determination, and you'll notice at times (as the player) he deliberately slows to a walk, reflecting the gravity of the situation. D-Pad Studios made great use of character interactions, environmental interactions, and interactions [i]with the players themselves[/i] to help us understand Otus'perspective.

We see this attention to visual detail with other characters, and the environments as well. Owlboy is a game [i]rich in aesthetics[/i] -- every scene is like a tapestry of pixel art, brought to life through smooth animations, a gripping soundtrack (by Jonathan Geer, the same person who created awesome tunes for the Cook, Serve, Delicious! games), and punchy sound effects.

As detailed as it may be, D-Pad Studio still manages to clearly separate decor from UI elements, and a majority of the in-game interactable objects. Minor complaint, I did (only [i]very occasionally[/i]) get confused in fast-moving sequences, being unable to make a split-second judgement on whether an object was interactable, or was part of the parallax scrolling background. On the whole, the game was visually easy to decipher.

More often it was the puzzles themeselves that eluded me, but in a good way. There's a healthy smattering of carrying-objects-to-places, stealth, mazes, etc., and they often prompt you to use Otus' flying abilities and your companions' abilities in clever and precise ways. As you might presume, there isn't much actual 'jumping between platforms' to be had, the challenge was moreso quickly and deliberately navigating through narrow passages, and it was a refreshing change from your typical 2D platforming experience. There are collectables in the form of Coins, but you're only able to trade them in for cosmetics and small upgrades to your existing stats, just a small consolation for those who would like to 100% the game, but otherwise not a focal point of Owlboy.

Did I mention carrying objects? Your companions are 'objects' too, you literally carry them around and have them fire projectiles like a weapon! I found this rather hilarious at first, then intruiging. The idea of carrying your companions around forms the core mechanic surrounding puzzles and combat, it's a crucial component for defeating bosses. Each boss in fact, more of a puzzle (requiring quick thinking, pattern recognition and using a smidge of reflexes), similar to bosses you encounter in games such as The Legend of Zelda series. I admit, I did die more than a few times during some boss fights, but they never seemed insurmountable, just challenging enough to be a delight when I finally pulled through.

So there you have it, Owlboy is a short and sweet game -- even playing really slowly, stopping to admire the scenery, and to see what each side character had to say, I took only 14 hours to finish it. I'd wager the less inquisitive, more goal-oriented can probably finish it in a few to several hours.


[b]TL;DR? [/b] Please do read it anyways, but if you insist:
[list]
  [*] Narrative focused: a succinct, relatable, well-written plotline
  [*] Great 'Show, Not Tell', audiovisual storytelling
  [*] Absolutely [i]outstanding[/i] pixel art & sound design
  [*] Familiar, yet refreshing puzzle solving / platforming / combat
[/list]


Oh yes one more thing -- as a [b]Linux[/b] user, I must mention that this game runs flawlessly! 60FPS (on 1280x720, pixel perfect resolution), no crashes, all in-game options function as intended, controller support is present (I've tested this with a Sixaxis PS3 controller). Thank you D-Pad Studios and Ethan Lee for porting this game to Linux. <3

[i](*Minor disclaimers: I've had this game gifted to me by a friend. Played through Owlboy once, over several sessions between May 2018 - April 2019. Played on Arch Linux, with Nvidia GTX 780, Intel Haswell Xeon E3-v1230v3. Played partially on Traditional Chinese (TW) and partially on English.) [/i]

I highly recommend Owlboy, and hope you like it too~! Thanks for reading. :)

I personally prefer a 'clean' style over retro aesthetics - think Hollow Knight vs Shovel Knight, as well-crafted as the latter is. Despite that, I was gobsmacked by the level of quality on display in Owlboy, and while pretty pictures alone don't make a game, it sure does help in this case. The animations are detailed and consistent, the world is sumptuously rich and lush, and when combined with an orchestral soundtrack and the lore of the game, it all seems very grand and epic when outside of the homely settlements. The pixel art generated most of the hype for this game, and on that front Owlboy delivers in spades.

The devs also deserve praise for tackling a rare bird - the ability to fly anywhere. This can completely remove challenge if done poorly, and while Owlboy doesn't always nail it, the movement and level of challenge is this game is mostly solid. It feels good to fly about, and while the control scheme can lead to few hectic moments when enemies are bombarding you later on, it generally all comes together well. The combat and puzzles generally involve you grabbing either teammates or environmental objects, and using them to blow away foes or flap your way into new areas. Both are relatively simplistic, but enjoyable nonetheless. The level design is pretty solid, with hubs leading to dungeons with their own unique environmental hazards and gimmicks, fairly standard stuff on the whole. Essentially, the game plays well and while boss fights can be taxing on the first attempt, there's nothing ridiculous.

Trying to measure the worth of a story is obviously subjective, but I thought that the worldbuilding and storyline were both well above average for an indie title. The plot is melancholic and avoids many common tropes, while embracing others - and the characters have more depth than you might expect. Otus emotes well for a silent protagonist, and there are some genuinely touching moments later in the game. The world of Owlboy is capably drawn, and the above aesthetic pairs well with the floating settlements in the sky, ancient history being scattered liberally throughout. It's significantly better than you'd expect just from looking at the screenshots.

Owlboy is a good adventure that rarely amazes, but the whole package far more than just the art direction. If you can pick it up on sale, a playthrough will stand you 7-10 hours and provide an enjoyable experience. The gameplay could be better, but the flaws aren't egregious enough to detract from some bold stylistic choices and a pretty unique game world to explore. Recommended for anyone who liked Iconoclasts and similar games.

Yet ANOTHER game that's been hyped up like crazy and yet the game is above average at best. God dammit.

Let's start with the gameplay since that's what's actually above average. So in this game, you control a character (Otus) that can fly around anywhere on the screen. He can do this without ever needing to come down into the ground. Obviously, this game therefore does not have any great platforming. While in the last level the game takes away your flying powers and therefore forces you to jump around "normally", even then the platforming was just "entertaining". Nothing mind-blowing.

Instead of platforming, the game is focused around puzzles, combat, and some stealth thrown in for good measure. That's one thing about this game: it has a lot of variety. I was never "bored" playing this game since every 20-30 minutes or so, the game mixes up how you're tackling scenarios. This is partly done through the 3 companions you'll get along your quest. Otus can fly around sure, but he needs his companions to attack enemies and other stuff
	• The first companion can shoot enemies to deal damage to them. Fairly straightforward.
	• The second companion can shotgun enemies (i.e. close range but powerful). He's also heavy and can activate "big" switches (i.e. switches that need a lot of weight on them) and his gun can be used as a lighter to burn plants or see stuff in the dark. All of this comes into play at various stages in the game
	• The third companion can web up enemies (not damage) and can "grapple" things. While grappling, Otus is completely immune to damage so it serves as a "dodge" of sorts. Again, all of this comes into play at various stages in the game.

So yea with Otus flying around everywhere and his 3 companions, the game manages to achieve a decent amount of variety. Unfortunately, while there is a lot of variety, there's not much quality to the game. That's because nothing is all that fun to do. 
	• This game has puzzles, but other games have far better puzzles. 
	• This game has combat, but other games have far better combat.
	• This game has stealth, but other games have far better stealth.

Get the idea? All of these separate elements are entertaining, but no individual element is AMAZING or anything. You never get any satisfaction from beating any of the segments in the game, since nothing is challenging. You can tank hits from most fights and even if you die, you can just restart from the same spot with no consequences. It would've been interesting if this game COMBINED separate aspects of its gameplay together. E.g. if for a boss you needed to use stealth or puzzles or whatever. But no. You can always tell when the game wants you to tackle a puzzle, combat, or stealth section and none of these elements are ever really combined in any meaningful way.

Also, while there is a decent amount of variety in the core gameplay, the same cannot be said about the progression system. You don't get any loot or exp from defeating enemies. In order to increase your health and weapons, you need to collect coins scattered throughout the game. Collect enough, and you'll automatically be given an upgrade by a shopkeeper (i.e. you cannot pick and choose. You always get the same upgrade at 250 coins, 500 coins, 750 coins, etc…). The thing is, there's not many things to get. There's 3 health upgrades and 3 weapon upgrades. The weapon upgrades themselves are very marginal. So you never feel any strong desire to collect the coins.

While the gameplay is above average, the story….. Not so much. Whoever wrote the story doesn't understand the following: Continuity, motivations, consistency, and making sense.

	• Continuity: So when the game starts, Asio (Otus's instructor) berates him for continually messing up and tells him to go to the village so that everyone can tell him how much he sucks. There's even this big dramatic scene where as you talk to people, the background shows sinister eyes growing bigger and bigger and Otus becoming sadder and sadder. Ok so based on what you're showing me, people don't like Otus. Gotcha. After that, you go to the village and turns out all the villagers (just 4) are acting friendly to Otus……. What the fuck? You showed me this dramatic sequence where Otus is hated by the village, but not really? Just the teacher hates him???? Ok…..
	• Motivations: Ok so just the teacher hates him. Whatever, the game just started, I can deal with that……. Why does he hate him? Because he fucked up a bunch of times? That's why the teacher is such an asshole to Otus and constantly puts him down? Ok…… so I guess this teacher is just a giant prick. Not a very interesting character but fine…… BUT WAIT. Near the end of the game, the teacher apologizes to Otus for everything he's done, hugs him, and asks for forgiveness…….. That is a GIANT change in character. What the hell caused this????? Is he a giant asshole or is he just "misunderstood". I don't know because the writer does a horrendous job in explaining the character's motivations and what he's thinking and why he's doing anything.
	• Consistency: Ok so the teacher is a lame character. Fine. What about the other characters? Welp, unfortunately, the characters you'll be spending time with (Otus and his 3 companions) never feel like real characters with real feelings. To be fair, there are MOMENTS where you see glimmers of greatness, but this is never CONSISTENT enough for you to get attached to any of the characters. The best example I can think of is near the middle. So a major city is destroyed by the villains. People DIE. The game emphasizes this with a dramatic cutscene and a graveyard that you're forced to walk through. The 1st companion was shown crying at the graveyard. Ok, I get that. You feel like you let everyone down. I really get that. The thing is, soon after, you're introduced to your 3rd companion and the game throws in a lot of jokes about how his parents are scared of your 2nd companion (in a funny way with characters freaking out with funny expressions) and your 3rd companion likes doing role play……. Really? You went from a city being blown up and people DYING to this? REALLY???!!!! Ugh.
	• Making sense: So there are 2 plots to this game. The 1st and main plot is you needing to stop the villains from getting 3 relics (hence all the dungeon exploring) so that the main villain cannot become all powerful and destroy the world. The 2nd plot is that an ancient civilization of "owls" existed that were very advanced but then their civilization fell into ruin. So there's this giant mystery about what happened. That's the last time I let awards dictate my purchase decisions.

Okay, let's not consider this a review, but rather a... first impressions.

I must preface by saying that I like some Indie games once in a while; Shovel Knight, the Messenger, and Cuphead are among my favorites. I believe Indie games are a good source for unique, exciting experiences that we can't get from certain larger, more famous, big-budget titles that shall remain unspecified.

However, I really despise when a developer tries to be "symbolic" and tries to "speak to its audience." At best, it makes you come across as a pretentious, artsy, attention seeker whose doctor hasn't prescribed the right dosage of Zoloft.

I mean, the presentation is fantastic - If it was a picture, I'd frame it and hang it on a wall. The characters and their motivations are clear, and the controls are... well, they're alright. Not too clunky, but not as precise as I would've liked for a platformer. But hey, I can fly!

But... I swear to God, this game hits too close to home, with possibly the only tutorial that managed to depress me more than Disorder. The prompt comes on the screen to press a certain button, I do, but then something breaks, and the game starts telling me I did it wrong. "ME?" I wanted to lash out, "I did exactly what you told me to!" (It's like living at your mom's house.)  Yes, I know it's part of the narrative, and it's a bit clever how they have the feeling of "the village black sheep" happen directly to the player through gameplay. A nice way to relate to the main character... but the way it was presented, I'm feeling more sorry for me than for our titular "OwlBoy." "I followed to instructions to a capital T, what more do you want!?" Ever have that teacher in school that tells you that you won't ever amount to anything, in spite of your effort and loyalty... mostly because of your face? 

Oh, yeah, by the way, he's mute, so he has no means to express himself - something for which the bigger, more able-bodied birds continually mock him, among other things. Instead of letting him develop and get a feel for things, they expect the world of him and -- wait a minute! Is the developer trying to provide commentary on modern economic society and the harsh standards placed upon developmentally challenged, preventing them from reaching their full potential? Boy, if I had a nickel for every time I've seen that. I didn't even have to read too deep into it; all I did was imagine all those birds were throwing shade at me, not the guy I'm playing as. In fact... they pretty much were!

So yeah, I play games to get better at something, and I rather strive to beat a really hard game than to (imagine if this was on physical media) beat my game really hard. This game's price tag is steep for an indie game, so I can't really recommend it for players who just want to have a good time. For those who place graphics above anything else, just download a free wallpaper and place it on your desktop.

Now, if you'll excuse me, it's late at night, and there's an Owl outside my window. Gonna go scream at it.

PS: No, I did not keep the game. I returned it for a refund with haste. I didn't pay for a game that's just going to act like they're my parents.

PPS: I don't remember much about the gameplay itself. All I remember was flying around a near empty town, and then fighting a few enemies. It really didn't leave much of an impact on me. Again, first impressions, not a review.

Come for the amazing pixel art, and then leave because the controls are annoying.

I bought this game for the art. No joke, no exaggeration, it was the art. Owlboy is absolutely a master work of pixel art that is largely unchallenged. In terms of the art style, the craftsmanship of this game is superb. Going through and taking screenshots of the game was a joy, and looking closely at how the artists did things in their limited palettes is something that will undoubtedly make me a better artist.

But for all of the good in terms of the art I sadly cannot recommend this game. There are several places where the controls are just FRUSTRATING to use. A good example of this is in the controls that you need to start flying. Pressing jump twice or pressing it once followed by up. Simple right? Well it would if I didn't try to use double-jump only for the second jump to CANCEL my flying because I rotated the control stick just a little tiny bit above the horizon so it registered it as an "up" press, thus making the second jump register the in-flight action of dropping.

And while I'm complaining about the controls, I'd like to point out that button remapping is NOT AVAILABLE in this game. Honestly, this irked me no end! I wanted to remap my controller but NOPE! Every game, EVERY GAME, should have the ability to change button layouts in-game. That's an accessibility standard and has been for a long time. I feel like there's no excuse not to have this feature anymore. I don't think I'm asking a lot with this.

Oh... and for how great this game's visual style is the designers seem to have an issue letting you see it at times. Virtually every 'dungeon' has at least one section devoted to having you in total darkness so you can't see what you're doing. Yeah, that might be how they wanted it but for a game that seems to sell itself partially on its beautiful art is seems like a bad decision to me. But then again, as stated, I got this for the art so there's my bias right there.

In terms of narrative, this game is also a bit of a failure. It sets up a grand lore and a huge world... but then destroys it before we can get a chance to see it. Like, literally a place that gets hyped up is destroyed before you can explore it. This game is a classic case of the designers not obeying the artist's mantra: "Show, Don't Tell".

And that's kind of a symptom of the game's larget tone problem. It's got cartoonish character designs, quirky and colorful characters, and funny dialogue... but the game's running story themes are abuse, emotional neglect, and the tragedy of death and loss. YIKES! Clearly not everyone was on the same page about what kind of game they were making.

I want to like this game. I want to like it's light metroidvania-style looping areas. I want to like it's interesting world. I want to like its characters. I want to enjoy it's lore... but there's not enough of any of those good elements for me to really get into it. It's a short game, taking as long as it did only because of mistakes I kept making due to the odd sort-of-twin-stick-shooter controls.

Get it for the amazing pixel art, and let it run for a few hours for the trading cards. But if you get it for the game you're going to need a bit of patience with some of the clunkier aspects of the design.

47964455.review:
I hate to leave a negative review on a game that looks and feels as incredible as this one does, but I was not at all satisfied by the end of my experience with Owlboy.

Owlboy is a beautiful-looking and -sounding game dampened by a starved and completely unsatisfying narrative. The game spends half of its length setting up a grand adventure in an interesting fantasy world filled with cute and lovable characters, but the game never gives you the journey it promises. If the first half of the game is the set-up, then the second half is the conclusion; there is no adventure or middle-section to fill the gap between them. It feels like there's an entire world out there, filled with magical landscapes and fantastical characters, that the game just never shows you. Instead, you get to meet the protagonist who is likeable and relatable but isn't given any chance to grow or change despite having more room for character growth than the cloud-filled skies around him.

It's a huge shame because what does exist of Owlboy is very good and very promising. The devs clearly put a lot of time and effort into the art and the music, putting the soul and spirit of their inspirations into it. But the quality of the presentation doesn't make up for the terrible narrative pacing and the lukewarm gameplay.

The bosses are forgettable and the ending doesn't feel one bit deserved. By the time I got 100% completion on this game (which took less than 10 hours, as you can see by my playtime) I felt like something horribly wrong must've happened during development of this game for it to ship with only the book-ends of an interesting story. This game did take 10 years to make, so maybe they felt they needed to speed up development to get it out the door in a reasonable amount of time. Maybe they finished the beginning and the ending first, got tired of working on it, and just shipped it without the middle so they could be done with it. Maybe they were just very confused about what kind of story they were trying to tell. Whatever the reason, the story suffers badly for it and it pulls the entire rest of the experience down with it.

I can't emphasize enough how unsatisfied I was with Owlboy. The $24.99 pricetag on this game is, frankly, inexcusable. I wouldn't recommend buying this game for $14.99. If I was a meaner person I would call it a scam, but I do respect the devs for taking the time and effort to make this game look and feel as incredible as it does. It's not a scam, it's simply an overpriced product that looks very beautiful from the outside but is ankle-shallow on the inside. If you want to support the devs and experience the best parts of this game, I fully encourage you to buy the soundtrack (since you will actually get your money's worth that way) and then watch your favorite YouTuber play it.

Owlboy has the foundation for an incredibly good RPG, one better than most independent studios would have the skills, love, and patience to craft. But sadly the foundation is all they were able to deliver. Definitely keep your eye on this studio, because they have a lot of potential, but right now your money is better spent elsewhere.

47560385.review:
With superb artwork, a sublime sountrack, and a powerful, understated story with rich characters, you owe it to yourself to check Owlboy out. It isn't perfect, but it is mostly remarkable and its flaws can't diminish a true artistic triumph.

From beginning to end, the writing and character development is dripping with brilliant pathos. The story will be most enjoyed by players with high levels of empathy or with life experience that will empower them to relate to the characters. It's been a long, long time since I've seen writing, direction, art, and music come together like this to convey emotion so powerfully in a retro/pixel/16bit-esque format. I was not expecting such depth when I got into this, nor was I expecting it to be so dark or to have such a mature emotional intelligence to it. That's not to say it's dour, though, as the creative team masterfully intermixes moments of levity in a way that let's you fall in love with it. However, some of the most cathartic moments of the game are missable/optional. I want to say that's a design error but this can also be a tool for rewarding exploration/completion and there are lots of games where missable events hold game altering revalations in an effective way (eg. Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice, Mass Effect 2, Final Fantasy VI). As such, while I can't fault them for this decision, it saddens me to think that some people will finish the game without [spoiler]talking to Asio at the overlook one last time before proceeding to the endgame[/spoiler] or [spoiler] will abstain from collecting the three gold disks that reveal a crucial element of the lore/backstory and will likely play into a potential sequel.[/spoiler]

The sum value of the storytelling isn't to say the execution is perfect. The game is strongest in its first half, where exploration/collection is minimal but still enough to feel really, really good alongside the AAA+++ retro-style pixel art. The flow/tempo of the game is perfect, with the story hitting all the right beats at all the right moments. At about the half-way point, especially if you're seeking to 100% the game, the flow gets broken by a few issues. First, there's no in-game map and effectively no fast travel. This means that while you're hunting for secrets, which is otherwise fun, you have to backtrack all the way in and all the way out of wherever you're exploring. Second, there starts to be a pretty significant gap between critical story elements. This isn't usually an issue in gaming but with such a short game as this, you feel it. Lastly, as you progress you encounter a few trial/error style fights/events that undercut the otherwise good gameplay. In the end, I do feel that collecting everything was worthwhile as the reward makes the endgame feel spot on. That said, I think the director could have executed their vision a bit better as far as the optional content goes.

The gameplay itself isn't overly impressive but the dev has put a lot of thought and care into it to compensate. At it's core, Owlboy is an action adventure shooter with a lot of variation in how you can approach any given scenario. You have three companions, each with stengths and weaknesses. With Owlboy's abilities and the abilities of those companions, you can interact with enemies and the environment in novel ways such that the shooter element is never bland. It's ultimately a fresh and fun take on the genre that neither enhances nor detracts from the game itself or one's enjoyment of the story.

The soundtrack is a creative blend of orchestral compositions and retro-style melodies, some of which are quite memorable. The quality of some audio files themselves, however, is inconsitant. Some tracks have a few cracks/pops or a light static that seems pretty clearly unintentional. Most players probably won't notice the issue and it likely depends on one's hardware but it really took me out of the moment in one dungeon in particular where I feel like I spent half the time checking my tweeters and making sure my home audio system wasn't the culprit. One positive thing that suprised me about the audio was that there's an impressive use of base that we don't often see in retro-style games like this, especially in the sub-audible frequency range. Anyone with transducers/shakers is in for a treat.

I feel confident that most people will fall in love with this game in some way or another. It's the type of game where, upon completion, the first thing I did was check out the dev's page to see what other creations they had to offer. There are some things Owlboy could do better but it hits home where it counts. 

P.S. This game has some awesome social media gifs, if you type Owlboy into the gif search bar. The Bouquins are my favourite.

[b]Owlboy[/b] is a beautiful game that unfortunately has more bark than bite. On the surface, it has the makings of an amazing game, but I found the core to be quite average. Maybe some will love it, maybe some will hate it. Take this recommendation as neutral. 
 
[h1][u]Positive:[/u][/h1]
[list]
[*]Great art and great music. The trailer should give you a good indication of the quality.
[*]Characters are delightful and very expressive. I especially like the [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1476771398]Gentleman fish[/url], the penguins and Otus’ surprised face. It’s also really nice that the party is essentially a group of outcasts. 
[*]Uncommon game mechanic, where you are essentially defenseless on your own, but carry objects/allies to overcome your weaknesses. It was interesting to try something new, and I found it worked well.
[/list]
 
[h1][u]Neutral:[/u][/h1]
[list]
[*]Some hidden areas are very difficult to find, sometimes with little to no indication that you can go through a wall.
[*]Cannon mini game was frustratingly difficult. Due to the falling speed, acceleration, and sensitive steering, you have very little time to react to upcoming sections and basically have to rely on muscle memory to get through. To collect all the coins in the game, you are required to collect all the rings in the mini game, which was very annoying to me. However, I can’t complain too much because collecting all the coins is optional. This allows you to buy the optional, overpowered final item.
[*]The amount of damage Otus can take in one hit can be shocking and the recovery time feels quite long. The large knockback can also be frustrating as it increases the likelihood of being slammed against a wall, which leads to more damage and staggering.
[*]Story was decent. It was not bad but also did not have much of an impact on me. Based on the trailer, I expected Owlboy to have a story befitting its charm, which is why I bought it in the first place. Unfortunately, I was let down since it didn’t live up to my expectation. 
[/list]

[h1][u]Negative:[/u][/h1]
[list]
[*]It’s a shame that a map wasn’t included. Even a basic map would have been very useful, especially if you haven’t played the game in a while. It would also make finding all the collectibles a little easier. 
[*]Based on how the game is designed, backtracking can be very long and boring. Since I am somewhat of an achievement hunter, it was very tedious to re-explore the areas after completing the game.
[*]Screen transitions can be very annoying and can feel unfair if you get hit by an enemy on the other side. I especially detested the screen transitions during the cannon mini game. Due to the high speeds, you simply don’t have enough time to react to the screen transition unless you already know what is coming up. 
[*]The following point has spoilers about the ending:[spoiler]Asio is very mean to Otus throughout the story, often proclaiming how disappointed he is in Otus. However, during the final cut-scene, Asio suddenly turns into a very kind mentor. This sudden change was very strange to me and ruined the ending.[/spoiler]
[/list]
 
[h1][u]Conclusion:[/u][/h1]
[h1]★★★☆☆ Just OK[/h1]

However, the most major issue I have is with the puzzles. The final issue I have with the game is the anticlimactic ending. It really wasn't satisfying in the slightest.  I expected more hidden treasures and passageways to find after the ending, but if you have already gone everywhere before you reached the ending, there's nothing else to do.

You know what saddens me the most? It's that the developers [i]cared[/i] about this game. Yet this game is shrouded in unbelievable amounts of bad design decisions that I can't wrap my head around it. Want to see what I mean for yourself? As an experiment buy this game, progress enough and get to the cannon minigame: it is so bad that it deserves to be studied by itself. Yet it's not an isolated incident but rather an encapsulation of everything this game fails to deliver.

So this is a game that was 10 years in the making, with [b]gorgeous[/b] visuals, no doubt about it. Apart from visuals, what does it bring to the table? It can be likened to run-and-gun levels of Cuphead (as opposed to boss sections of it) which tries and fails to tell a captivating story. Where and how does it fail? Because it's a story of heroics-gone-wrong, with little player agency. It's like storyteller is shouting at us, knowing in full that we can't resort back: "Why? What did we wrong? Tell me, help me improve!" But no, you will succeed in failing: that's the only thing game allows you to do. Don't get me wrong, I'm not particularly against failure or good-deed-gone-wrong, but here it's at a complete odd with the scenery. It's pastel, colorful, cheerful, playful. Even the "big bad"s are beaked robots calling themselves pirates. Completely impossible to instill a sense of seriousness, apart from all the loss we're dealt. For player growth through failure there needs to be a more somber tone than this game provides.

Also gameplay is incredibly frustrating. How did developers agreed to implement them I'll never know but I can guess: spending 10 years on [i]any[/i] is a surefire way to get tunnel visioned: your bad ideas don't appear bad anymore, after all those are the only ideas around. And you learn to walk around problems they present because you've been dealing with them from day 1. So all in all this might have been the only game they knew, so there was no problem in shipping it like this because they couldn't imagine any other Owlboy anymore.

What do I mean by frustrating? I told player agency being limited from a narrative standpoint: This holds true from gameplay side too. You don't shoot, you carry teammates that shoot for you (you do the aiming, so it's not automatic) which shouldn't be too different from otherwise but it is: Whenever you take damage you drop your gun, so you need to reequip it while trying to dodge tons of enemies swarming you. Enemies swarm you and most have the same colour palette as you do, therefore making it almost impossible to distinguish who is who in the midst of chaos. Further, levels are large and displayed in limited portions with transitions being abrupt and discontinuous. When you get exit the screen from left you enter the next one from right though since level is loaded there will be active enemies that will damage you making you unable to fight back and make you not distinguish who's who. I can't begin to express how frustrating that was. (Solution: keep your character fixed and let environment roll around you a la Cave Story. Was is impossible in this game's context? Not my problem!)
Another thing: this game can't decide if it wants to be action packed or tactical. Movement is slow, there are cooldowns, enemies are not very energetic, but on occasion you'll need to mash buttons or move quickly. Why? What do you want me to do, game?!

I may finish the game, I may not, but either way don't buy into the hype that was gorgeous visuals. Watch some in-depth gameplay first.

45142568.review:
EATING A CAKE ON A UNICYCLE

Owlboy offers best-in-class pixel graphics, extremely well-composed music, brilliant story... and ridiculously sloppy controls (both controller and WASD+mouse). Combined with infuriating bosses, this game promises great gameplay only to crap all over you when you are fighting some of the crucial fights.

There is a lot going on on the screen, which doesn't mix well with the whole concept of you lugging your gunners. You get hit, you lose them, you end up flying across the room, losing control of your character. Sometimes you recover in mid air, sometimes you end up on the wall and have to wait what feels like ages before you're back on your feet - all this while the baddie is relentlessly attacking you. Then you eventually recover, spawn your gunner, cycle back and forth till you get the right one, while trying to avoid all the chaos headed your way. You press jump to fly, but sometimes you press up first, so jump just cancels out the flying (???), meaning you drop to the floor, only to be hit by something and oh boy here we go again. To top it all off, you can't just shoot bosses. You have to figure out their hocus-pocus voulnerability, which wouldn't be a problem, if it were either explained or hinted at properly. Get ready to restart some checkpoints while you figure out what the hell you are supposed to do.

These are just a few gripes off top of my head. Not even Cuphead got me this mad. This game is like a bastard child of the original Castlevania and any (all) of the NES Megaman games - you know, the games that, due to hardware limitations, were short, so developers would inflate difficulty levels to artificially extend their length.

Disappointment is not the word. I can see how much effort was put into development of this game and I genuinely love the world, and the atmosphere, the sense of humour, the characters and the right amount of dialogue, how clever the story is, the meticulous, top-notch pixel graphics, the music etc. I even like the puzzles - something that most games tend to get wrong. So I get the urge to grab my controller and delve back into the world of Owlboy... but then I remember how annoying the controls can be (the bit with the pendulum in the caves...), and how easy it is to lose your footing during boss enqounters (the boss that hurls scimitars at you on the ship), how touchy the collision detection can be and so on.

It's a real shame - especially that we've all been starved of immersive, well made games nowadays. Imagine you've not had anything to eat for a week and then somebody offers you a huge, tasty cake, but under one condition: that you have to eat it on the rooftop of a moving bus, while balancing on a unicycle and avoiding bricks being thrown at you.

Owlboy's a pretty good Metroidvania overall. Not the best I've played (that goes to Ori and the Blind Forest or Hollow Knight), but it's a solid title that I'll remember. One of my bigger gripes with this game is that sections in a stage are often divided by screens (but still loaded), so there's a pretty good chance that you could cross a screen-transition and immediately run into enemies or thorns that you couldn't see as part of the next screen and didn't necessarily know about, Also, enemies can follow you across these screen transitions, and still hit you from other screens, which can get pretty annoying.

Aesthetically, this game hits all the strong points. The pixelated worlds and the Legend-of-Zelda esque soundtrack can keep you immersed in this beautiful, majestic world in the sky. Movement tends to be pretty solid as well, thanks to solid use of rolling in the air. It's just a shame that in terms of gameplay, the game can often get held back by seemingly "unfair" damage due to what I mentioned above with screen transitions. 

I'd recommend Owlboy after getting through the practically perfect/very good Metroidvanias (Ori, Hollow Knight, Guacamelee 2, Steamworld Dig 2, and La Mulana), though I would not buy Owlboy at full price, since Owlboy's overall content can seem like it just isn't quite enough for $25. At $10 or below though, this game is more than worth its price.

Pretty much everything that has been already said. Visually, Owlboy is one of the best looking sprite games I have seen in awhile. And the music ain't too bad either, though other than the main theme and 2 other tracks near the end, very few of them really stood out. But I do recall the ost having primarily orchestrals and chiptones, playing a lot towards that SNES nostalgia (which the whole game does well already) while still feeling like something new and modern.

The story is simplistic(at least on the surface), but that is kinda part of the charm. Even though you don't really spend that much time with any of characters for very long, you still get an idea of who they are and their motivations. The only two gripes I got is that the game sometimes feels a little too mean to Otus, which is an ongoing theme a good chunk of the game. The second is how abrupt the ending felt, which was already soured a bit by a character cliche/trope that I can't stand. There is also a sidequest that goes much deeper into the lore, plus a few other hidden cutscenes unlocked by doing specific things.

Controls took a bit of time getting used to. Your mileage will likely vary since I don't play these sorts of games normally (and I still kind of wonder if being left-handed also played some part in it), I'm pretty sure anyone who's played a lot of games of this style would pick it up well. The good news, it always kept feeling like I was improving by the time bosses/segments got harder, usually being able to get through the worst of it within a few tries and patience. However, it's very easy to loose your momentum in just one hit. Since not only do you let go whatever character you're carrying at the time, but touching any wall while being knocked back means more time wasted just to recover. 

Also if you ever want to get 100%, you have to to get good at the cannon minigame. Pretty much half of the game's achievements are locked behind it. From own experience and by reading other community feedback it is definitely the hardest part.

Overall, I still thought Owlboy was a nice game. Couple flaws aside, it was very obvious that a lot of care and detail was put into it (before I was even aware of its development history), so it is worth checking out. Although it is fairly short, something that I would probably recommend waiting for a good sale.

Owlboy is a 2D Platformer/Metroidvania-esque game with a very nice spin on main character design: a mute eponymous Owlboy who is NOT a jump-and-shoot-style character, like a certain Reploid or italian plumber! Otis, the Owlboy, is not the shooter, but rather whoever he carries with him is. Interesting mechanic, inwhich you must decide which character is best suited for the situation! 

Upon starting the game, it is very plain the pixel art done has a lot of love put into it. The spritework is refreshing to watch and the environments you will be exploring meticulously designed down to the pixel. The story, I feel, progresses at a reasonable pace. It did a good job of keeping me engaged, keeping me wondering what will happen, what dangers are ahead? It kept me more engrossed because this character is not very capable of combat, but rather relies on a character he will carry to do the fighting. Very similar to how Ori relies on Sein's power to blast monsters with fireballs, Otis relies on friends for cover-fire.

I also very much liked how it was not very difficult to learn how to control Otis' flying later on. There's plenty of space in the beginning levels to practice learning how Otis moves and controls, so you will be ready for later sections that demand more precise platforming. I had little to no difficulty proceeding through the game's later levels either. 

And similar to Ori and the Blind Forest, you are rewarded for exploring areas that are out of the way of your main objective. There are things to find, knickknacks to unlock, good treasure hunting for the completionists and adventurous players! 

The characters are likeable and each have their own easiy identifiable mannerisms and persona. Some change views as the game progresses as well! And those that do teach some very deep lessons I feel are very important to carry with oneself. 

Owlboy is a wondrous game to play from start to finish, and would play it again had I the time to do so. If you enjoy platformers but want something a little different, give Owlboy a play. It is worth every cent.

Owlboy is a unique platformer, in the sense that it's more of a hybrid platformer/shooter since you can fly everywhere. It's technically a metoridvania but I wouldn't group it under what you'd generally expect from something of that genre. As a result I can see why if someone came in with certain expectations and standards then they might be let down.

On a side note, I played on keyboard and mouse, and I almost never do for traditional platformers, so I'd highly recommend that peripheral. You need to aim a lot of the time so that should be self explanatory. The controls in this sense were very responsive and smooth and felt pretty natural to me.

While it does share aspects of metroidvanias in the inherent progression and ability to move around going back and forth, the game gives a more open-world feeling, even if it is a bit of an illusionary one. What I mean by this is there's a main world area, but in the end you mostly only go through certain paths anyways and in that area there's not really much to do anyways.

What the game really excels at is the charm of it's world and the sense of adventure you get from it. The gameplay supplements it and really gives you a lot of freedom to tackle many situations, from the puzzles to the boss fights. It doesn't really hold your hand but at the same time the conclusion you need to reach is often pretty intuitive. 

While I personally enjoyed the game a lot while I was playing it, finishing it left me a little lost. This is due to the story, which is kind of just a "oh yeah we have to do this now so lets do it" and looping that, until the end where something being revealed changes a lot of the meaning of what the whole adventure was about. The whole backstory is very interesting but I do not feel as if everything ties up very nicely. There is something you can unlock only after finishing the game and it lets you think even more on the whole world and how everything goes together, but it still left me wanting more of some kind of closure, despite there being some.

In the end, I feel like the game was a very charming little story that just barely didn't reach what I would consider something of a masterpiece. It's really unfortunate but I'd still recommend it to others who like the unique gameplay and appreciate that relatively pleasant experience.

Oh and of course the visuals and audio were amazing.

First off, the animation and pixel art is gorgeous.  The orchestral soundtrack is epic and sets the tone perfectly! 

The story is far darker than I expected, but not overtly violent or gory.  If you watch Star Wars cartoons (and similar) with your kids you can safely let them play this. I use mouse and keyboard, and can't seem to get good enough at controlling the crosshair simultaneously with flying. The sudden difficulty-spikes in the bossfights becomes annoying and rather tedious. But, these are my only real criticisms of this charming work of art.
