43813093.review:
As the whimsical tale about a mute owl child and his happy-go-lucky human best friend, “Owlboy” fits comfortably in the gray area between platformers and Metroidvanias. It does not have to fully commit to either to stick out as a cute little pixel gem – one, however, that is not free of flaws.

Visually, the game is adorable, with colorful environments, quirky characters and excellent sprite work. The soundtrack also matches the overall style and the tracks range from fine to quite stunning. The game's presentation is without a doubt what draws many players in and the game definitely fulfills its artistic promises. Based on these aspects alone some might be surprised to discover a story that is at times remarkably dark and betrays a rather grand ambition with a lore that could under different circumstances parallel the depth of even “Hollow Knight.”

However, the scope of this underlying story turns out to be much larger than a game this short can handle. After all, even completionists will hardly spend more than 15 hours on their first playthrough. As a consequence, many interesting aspects of the game’s universe feel unexplored and character development sometimes rushed, with barely enough time for players to fully process everything that seems to be going on in the background before the game is already over.

With regard to gameplay, “Owlboy” works best when the focus lies on exploring and puzzle-solving while it struggles with combat. The relatively cumbersome controls can make the game unnecessarily frustrating at times, particularly when quick thinking is required during boss fights - of which there probably should have been fewer. For the most part, however, the game is relatively forgiving and closer to the easier end of the spectrum when compared to many other indie platformers and Metroidvanias of recent years. Thus, the occasional moments of rage do not overshadow the strengths of this good-natured title.

In the end, “Owlboy” is far from perfect, but still a recommended experience for those who wish to go on an emotional journey through another charming pixel world; even if players who truly enjoy what it has to offer will probably wish that there were more.

43412486.review:
Owlboy is, plainly, a mixed bag. There are some moments that feel awesome, and some that feel very unfair and frustrating. I will attempt to elaborate upon it's strengths and weaknesses, in order from best to worst.

The best part of Owlboy is, in my opinion, the characterization. It's obvious that a lot of love was put into making every moment relatable or funny, and I loved almost every interaction and dialogue. That leads me to...

The art is, of course, also very impressive. It's 16 bit aesthetic is almost forgotten entirely when put into context of how much love and effort was put into it's animations and design. The game looks absolutely beautiful, especially during key story moments. This nicely transitions to...

The story is... passable. It's not bad, but it's not really amazing either. Strong characterization makes for highlights inbetween honestly uninteresting segments. Some story elements are fantastic (such as the enigmatic "Loop"), while others are unexplored, unanswered, and unfinished. Not in a "Man, I really want to know more about X!" way, but a "Wait, what was X about? Well, I guess we're never talking about it again. Whatever.". But all this niceness could be forgotten thanks to...

The gameplay. Hoo boy. The gameplay for Owlboy is bland at best, and infuriating at worst.

Exploration is probably the most acceptable mechanic, and something they clearly put some thought into, but the lack of map makes it easy to get lost in the similar halls and corridors within each zone, and it can ultimately feel impossible to get that last Buccanary coin since you have no idea where to look besides the rough area.

Combat, however, is what really cements my overall negative opinion of the game. It overshadows the fantastic characters, beautiful art, decent story, and acceptable exploration with how awful it feels. Rather than attacking things directly, your only true method of damaging enemies is by carrying people with guns who shoot for you. Getting hit, however, not only knocks you back, but makes you drop whom/whatever you're carrying. If you fall to the ground, you additionally have to get back into the air, as you can't carry people while you're walking. The screenshake during some fights is intense, contributing to the visual clutter you can often find yourself trapped in as you take hit after hit, unable to recover. The game is thankfully merciful with most of it's respawn points, which is the only saving grace of some of the more infuriating bosses. Overall, your character feels so unnecessarily weak that some parts are genuinely un-fun, and frankly, the other aspects of the game couldn't make up for the segments in which I died over a dozen times thanks to honestly unfair mechanics.

My overall purchasing conclusion is thusly: If you're willing to put up with the frustrating combat mechanics and drag yourself through some of the less-compelling moments in the story, you will find moments to cherish in Owlboy. Pick it up on sale IF you're interested, but don't come in expecting it to engage you if you aren't already. At full price, it probably isn't worth it either way.

Some may look at Owlboy and wonder why it wasn't wildly popular like Undertale and Minecraft, other indie games that certainly put in as much effort as the developers at D-Pad. This leads me to my conclusion that Owlboy is somewhat of the essence of an Indie Game. Not in a "The perfect example", but "The perfect summary". The love put into Owlboy is more than apparent at every turn, but it is still a very flawed creation. Undertale explodes with character and story, and Minecraft evolved to become deeper and more engaging over it's long, open development, and still recieves updates! But those games are rare, nearly-flawless masterpieces, and those aspiring to achieve their success are almost assuredly going to be disappointed.

Not every indie game can be Undertale or Minecraft. Sometimes, they must settle for being Owlboy.

Edit: The music was so forgettable I literally forgot about it in my review.

I really never thought I'd be writing a review for a game. But this game has left such a sour taste in my mouth even a week after finishing it. 

Repetitive, uninteresting, and poor design choices, and a hefty price tag for such a short and clunky game. It's far from a 10/10.

It's a game that reels you in at first, with interesting gameplay, story, characters, etc. The first two hours are fantastic. And it just plummets after you finish the first dungeon. Characters become cliched and boring. Combat is the same and there's literally no variance other than people leaving your party for story-reasons. Really gorgeous graphics but the gameplay is so clunky and the level design is terrible later on. You can really tell that they spent most of the ~9 years in development drawing the designs. You never want a frustrate a player with your level design choices and the devs do just this. Too much focus on making a dungeon unique has made them unfun and frustrating, such as a dungeon featuring a darkness mechanic... with an FOV of literally the player in a dungeon featuring spiked walls and enemies jumping out of walls you can't see. Sure they're unique -- in how bad the features they feature are. Midgame to endgame is full of frustrating level design and boring and lazily designed bosses. To make the boss fights worse, they all have so much HP that it takes ~2 minutes of repetitive shooting to complete one of any stages of a boss. Now, I'm not a big fan of singleplayer games. Having grown up on classics such as Super Smash Bros Melee and dumping hundreds of hours into TF2, I considered myself a multiplayer gamer only. Owlboy is a superb platformer that has amazing music to go along with it. I've found myself sitting around in one place and not dashing through the game to just listen to the incredible soundtrack that they've included as part of the base game. I also debated picking up the soundtrack, because it is truly serene and deserves to be listened to in focus. Even if the gameplay wasn't great, I would still recommend this game purely for the beautiful soundtrack that the developers have matched perfectly with the relaxed setting of the ame.

Owlboy's gameplay is incredibly simple, but also retains a challenging aspect at the same time. My one main gripe with the game is that some enemies and bosses (specifically the Floating Continent Boss) are difficult to figure out how to defeat without resorting to the Internet, but otherwise the gameplay is smooth and comfortable, and works effortlessly with a mouse and keyboard. [quote=][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/12146432-La-Cruceta-Inquieta/][b]La Cruceta Inquieta[/b][/url], mentor de Steam[/quote]

Tras casi una década de trabajo, su reducido equipo desarrollador decidió que ya era hora de lanzar un juego, SU juego, demostrando que las prisas nunca son buenas y haciendo palpable la casi infinita dedicación puesta en él y que, más allá de seguramente satisfacer su ansia perfeccionista, por suerte, también repercute beneficiosamente en nosotros como consumidores. La espera mereció la pena. 

“Owlboy” nos sitúa en un colorido mundo de islas flotantes en el cielo donde la vida es sencilla y reina una calma aparente bajo la siempre atenta vigilancia de los búhos. No obstante, pronto los acontecimientos comenzarán a torcerse y, bajo el manto volador de Otus, un joven mudo e inseguro aprendiz de búho, tendremos que hacer frente a distintas amenazas y enemigos que pondrán patas arriba nuestro hogar pero que afectarán a algo que irá mucho más allá de lo local para terminar evitando la total destrucción de nuestro mundo. Así, con la ayuda de una serie de compañeros que iremos conociendo poco a poco y que tendrán su influencia en el "gameplay", no sólo emprenderemos un largo viaje con aquel propósito, sino que además asistiremos al proceso de la evolución de nuestro protagonista desde la máxima inseguridad hasta su aceptación como parte esencial de la comunidad y al redescubrimiento de antiguas verdades ocultas sobre sus antepasados. No sé si premeditadamente o no, pero la trama de “Owlboy” me ha recordado y me ha parecido que posee una gran influencia de la saga “The Legend of Zelda” de Nintendo, lo cual no es sino una buena noticia porque es en las primeras, originales y mejores entregas en las que parece haberse apoyado.

De esta forma, pese a que la historia tiene momentos álgidos de gran interés, intensidad y emotividad, no cabe duda que lo que genera verdadero interés por “Owlboy” es su llamativo aspecto gráfico. Es cierto que apenas innova en técnicas que ya se usaban hace años en la época de los 16 o incluso 32-bits, pero hacía tiempo que no se rescataba esta forma de hacer de una forma tan detallada y perfeccionista, ofreciendo un apartado visual que, sin duda, entrará directamente por los ojos de aquellos que aprecien el pixel art como forma expresiva en los videojuegos. Es además con esta técnica no sólo como se han materializado los sprites de los personajes o los escenarios, ambos con sus respectivas fantásticas animaciones, sino que el dilatado tiempo de desarrollo también ha servido para enfatizar los momentos importantes de la trama con cinemáticas que hacen uso de ella y que son absolutamente espectaculares y eficaces en trasladarnos la intensidad y grandiosidad de cada momento que describen. Un diez en este apartado. 

Por fortuna, el buen hacer del estudio de desarrollo no se ha limitado a estos apartados y, en lo que a la música y sonidos respecta, el resultado es difícilmente mejorable. Tanto la banda sonora compuesta con instrumentos reales como los contundentes efectos sonoros nos acompañarán a la perfección durante nuestro viaje y nos harán sentir con más intensidad a través de nuestros oídos lo que a través de nuestros ojos ya poseía fuerza suficiente para suscitar nuestro interés. Así, las variadas composiciones nos harán pasar por el proceso que va desde la tranquilidad de nuestro hogar inicial a la épica de las batallas a las que haremos frente y al casi misticismo de las vivencias interiores de Otus y de su relación con la civilización olvidada que lo precedió.

Finalmente, como no podía ser menos, “Owlboy” se afianza en los pilares sólidos de un género tan popular hoy día como es el de los "metroidvania". Si bien no se trata de un videojuego dentro de los más puristas del género, sí que nos dará la sensación de estar jugando a un título de este tipo pero, al igual que ocurre con la trama, con ciertos toques de algo parecido a la saga “Zelda” con sus pinceladas de aventura de acción y salpicaduras de rol. Sea como sea, deberemos controlar a Otus, el cual, generalmente y sobre todo al inicio, será casi totalmente dependiente de sus compañeros para hacer frente a los enemigos que nos encontremos. De esta forma el juego también adquiere tintes de una especie de "dual-stick shooter" simplificado en el que, por un lado, controlaremos el vuelo de Otus y, por otro, la dirección del ataque del personaje correspondiente que estemos llevando. Esto que al principio parece un tanto extraño puesto que nuestro personaje parece totalmente vulnerable cuando está sólo (podemos elegir esto en cualquier momento), pronto se hará costumbre y se nos hará sencillo alternar entre personajes, o bien para vencer enemigos con una debilidad determinada, o bien para abrir nuevos caminos que previamente no podíamos alcanzar como en todo buen "metroidvania" ocurre. Son estos caminos los que conforman un mapa bastante extenso y muy variado en cuanto a localizaciones y situaciones pero que, siendo del género que es, posee un fallo impensable: la inexistencia de un mapa. Esto que, como digo, ya forma parte esencial del género dado que siempre se fomenta la exploración, no está presente en “Owlboy” y, sea por olvido o por decisión de diseño para hacer nuestra tarea más dificultosa, resulta bastante incómodo a la hora de buscar secretos y ahondar más en su trama. A pesar de todo, esto no puede empañar un esquema de jugabilidad que nos mantiene en todo momento entretenidos e, incluso a veces, en exceso con momentos sin un minuto de descanso pero que hacen ver el encomiable trabajo del estudio por ofrecer un producto que varía en todo momento y que casi no deja lugar para la repetitividad.    

En definitiva, “Owlboy”, sin ser de los más purista dentro del género, es uno de los "metroidvania" más originales de los últimos tiempos, y su valía se aprecia aún más sabiendo el dilatado tiempo de desarrollo que se le ha dedicado y el ingente trabajo que hay detrás de él en pos de producir un videojuego que no deje tiempo para el aburrimiento mientras nos deja estampas y momentos que difícilmente olvidaremos.

https://youtu.be/JIrkNxwauVo

Owlboy was released recently for XBox and PS4, which made me go search in my game library to see if I already own it. I found it and spent 10 hours delighted with the game. Simply gorgeous.

I think the introduction says it all, but I suspect you're expecting to listen a few more lines. Owlboy has been in development for almost 10 years and went almost unnoticed when it was released on PC. It is a puzzle platformer in which we solve some relatively easy puzzles to advance. Otus, our main character, sees his land attacked by pirates and creates a group of friends, consisting of characters once devalued by their peers, to try to save their world. It has to be said that it is a very well written story, with well characterized characters, each one with its own history, more or less detailed to the point that we sincerely care about all of them. Even some of the side characters or villains are extremely well represented. It's a linear story, with a small twist at the end, but very well set and explained. My only problem with the story, and not wanting to spoil it, is the final battle. In addition some of the dialogues become rather extense, although I believe that little or nothing could be excluded from the final product.
Graphically the game was a surprise. I expected a Shovel Knight-like artstyle but the way they used the pixelart in this game, combining it with high-resolution graphics, immense details on the movements and expressions. The construction of worlds and scenarios goes far beyond the games that try emulate retro games. For example Otus does not speak but the facial and body expressions details are more than enough to perceive all their emotions and we can even imagine a whole dialogue just with them. Recently I spoke about the attention given to detail in Sea of Thieves and Owlboy is another great example of how to build a world and how to use art to do something well made.
The game soundtrack does not disappoint and remarkably follows the tone of each. When we are quietly exploring the world the music is calm and relaxing, and when we are in a fighting section or when we need to do fast movements the music becomes more intense and dynamic. I liked the sound effects for each one of the movements and actions of the characters and even the sounds for the dialog boxes, and although nothing is extraordinary, undoubtedly a competent job was made.

How do you play this? I tried to play it as a twin stick shooter, but at one point I got tired of it because it's so much easier to simply use keyboard and mouse. There was nothing fundamentally wrong with the configuration of the controller, but when the game reached a difficulty spike, I did not have enough skill to overcome a boss or a more demanding section, so I choose for the easier solution... change the controller.

In this game we control Otus which as a standalone character does very little. He flies, twirls, and spins. The secret and charm of the game is that he can pick up any of his three friends and take advantage of their different abilities to progress through levels or areas that we would not have access to without them.

Although the amount of enemies is not great, combat rarely seems repetitive because the way they appear, leads us to use different techniques to overcome them in each of those moments.
The puzzles are relatively simple and often obvious, which means that you have the feeling that boss battles have a remarkable difficulty spike and required me numerous attempts to outcome most of them. The fact that the controls were somewhat confusing, which made me do multiple mistakes also did not help. In sections where we have time to think there was no big problem other than the frequent annoyance of picking up the friend rather than picking up an item or picking the wrong character, but during quick sequences a mistake ruins everything and in those times it becomes frequent.
There are lots of collectibles and hidden areas that reward both exploration and the repetition of some of the areas when we gain access to new characters. Defeating enemies in a certain way also gives you access to new items.

In a nutshell the game is this. A lovely world with characters with whom we can easily create a relationship. Graphically it managed to impress me by the way they included so many detail in the pixel art. A very engaging story. A game and also an experience that I highly recommend. Now available on all platforms, if you have the opportunity to play it do not discard this game.

42462403.review:
In short, Owlboy is a fantastic albeit short game for its price. For a concise review, there is a pros-and-cons list at the bottom of this review.

Owlboy is a 2D platform adventure game, with much more emphasis on adventure than platforming. The gameplay is unique in that you control Otus, an owl boy (hah) capable of flight. However, his only attack is a spin that merely stuns enemies. For combat, he picks up his companions who can shoot the enemies for him in a somewhat similar vain to how a twin-stick shooter would play out. Different companions have different attacks, and all of them are to be utilized throughout the game's progress. The game auto-saves rather frequently, so you can save and quit at any time and pick up right where you left off. 

There's no levelling up or weapon upgrades, only different characters to use when the story calls for them. This keeps the enemies rather balanced throughout the game; it never feels like the enemies are damage sponges (something many adventure games seem to suffer from in my experiences). Instead, there are coins scattered around the land, and picking up the coins and taking them to a shop nets you upgrades that either increase your max HP or weapon range, or give you a cosmetic to wear. The upgrades are unlocked in a systematic order, so you don't have to worry about unlocking the "wrong thing first". However, it's impossible to grind for these coins; there are a finite number of coins in the land, and picking them up permanently registers that coin in your inventory. There is a section in the pause menu that allows you to see how many coins you've picked up in an area, as well as the total number of coins in that area. Exploring any area, even a little bit, often yields coins, so it's suggested - but not required - to investigate everything as you're progressing through the game.

Each dungeon and segment of the game consists of many puzzles and some boss fights; none of the puzzles felt tedious, boring or overly difficult, and the bosses all felt unique, most of them have at least some creative gimmick required to defeat them. Some bosses in the later segments of the game felt pretty difficult, but not impossibly difficult. Fortunately, if you die anywhere or in a boss fight, you respawn with full health at the beginning of the room you died in, or outside the boss area. This makes dying less frustrating but still something you want to avoid. Regarding the dungeons themselves, they're mostly linear but don't [i]feel[/i] linear, with backtrack routes and shortcuts that are very difficult to miss. You can get through them without a map, which is good because there is no map system in this game. This is only bad if you're a completionist going for the achievements, but main-storywise it's not an issue.

Overall, Owlboy is a fantastic 2D action-adventure game with a story that leaves an extremely strong first impression and continues to impress as you progress. You can really feel the effort the developers put into the game, its environment and its conveyance, and I was surprised at how short the credits list was at the end. 
[list]
[h1]Pros[/h1]
[*] Unique yet intuitive gameplay
[*] Compelling and developing story.
[*] Unique and consistent characters, both main and minor.
[*] Enemy and level design that's not frustratingly difficult but also not boringly easy.
[*] Amazing soundtrack that compliments the tone of each section of the game.
[*] Any exploration is rewarded, and is completely optional.
[h1]Cons[/h1]
[*] Relatively short main story, approximately 6 hours long.
[*] No map feature, although one isn't really needed unless you're going for 100% completion.
[*] Overall linearity yields almost no replay value, unless you're going for 100% completion.
[/list]
In conclusion, Owlboy is a wonderful game that I think is definitely worth experiencing, but $25 USD is a rather steep price for 6 hours of quality story. Definitely pick it up if you can easily afford to spend $25 on a great but short game, or if it goes on any kind of sale.

42046247.review:
TL; DR: a very great game for those of you who prefer to sit back and enjoy a good story

(minor spoilers)

    in today’s modern age of massive multiplayer MOBA games and 100 player battle royal games it seems that the glory days of single player games has long past, it’s sad that the very games we grew up playing are no longer considered good by many inside the industry, before the internet all we had were the amazing stories that came from the hard work and dedication developers put into their games. 

    as time went on games became less and less original as players demanded sequels to their favorite games, developers started re hashing old stories to make them seem new, and most games tried their best to shoehorn in a multiplayer mode. the beauty of videogames, the story, was left to the sidelines.  
   
    that is why I’m very glad to see many smaller developers commit to the single player stories that made this medium of entertainment what it is, and Owlboy is a great addition to that medium.

    in Owlboy you play as Otus a young, mute owl who is put under the tutelage of a well-respected mentor named Asio. at the start of the game you see parts of Outs' training and consecutive failings. his inability to learn the fundamentals of being and owl, even his inability to fly like the rest of the owl children. this game tries its best to tell you that Otus is a complete failure, you would be inclined to think that the game is selling Otus short however as the story progresses you start to see that no matter what Otus does, he always seems to fail at it. from patrolling the town looking for pirates, only to have the pirates attack while he is being distracted.

    as the game progresses you get the feeling that while Otus is making great strides through the story, he isn’t really making any improvements, he's not learning anything new. But from what he lacks in his learnings he makes up for in the friends he makes along the journey. the story seems to be telling more the groups adventure as opposed to just Otus. since he is mute all the narration is done through second parties. while you may be the one controlling Otus it is his friends that are telling the story.

    and what a story that is!


highlights:

-great story: as told through the second parties. while Otus does not talk or make any major improvements I still felt accomplished and (somewhat) satisfied with the ending.

-great soundtrack: the music and ambiance are both smooth and fitting for each environment, it never feels like the music is overpowering the mood.

-great art style, its pixel art, what's not to love?  in my opinion you don’t need realistic or fancy graphics you just need a good art style

-amazing characters: a lot of single player games nowadays I talk to a person only once unless I absolutely must, however the characters and their stories had me checking in on them whenever I was able to just to learn more about the world I was in which leads me to...

- the lore: arguably one of the hardest parts of telling a story is finding a setting and building a world around the story. it’s easy to go from start to finish, but only truly great works take time to care about the before, the after, and the stops you make along the way. this game takes its time between the bosses to shed some light about the world and why you are undergoing the quest that you are on.

the only issue I had with the game was the ending. not in a sense that it was bad but that it kept things very vague, I can understand completely from a story telling standpoint why the developer did this, but I was left with many questions that were left unanswered chief among which was, what happened sir fish after the story ended?

9/10- I hate giving perfect scores
in all honesty though at $25 this game is worth every penny, if you ever see it on sale I would highly recommend getting this.

42039293.review:
Owlboy is an okay game. It has a lot of really impressive aspects, but the game itself ends up doing little, in my opinion.

The pixelart is really amazing, and obviously the main draw of the game. There is a lot to look at and it looks really good. The only complaint I have it that it doesn't differentiate between foreground and background well at all, in some places... Still, if you're interested in pixel art, definitely take a look at Owlboy. It also has one of the best nightskies! Not a lot of attention is typically played to the sky, but they've done a great job.

The music is also surprisingly good! But it's almost "film music". It sounds very good, and it complements the scenes very well, but in a very disney movie-like manner. The story also fits into this, I think.

One surprising aspect that I really enjoyed was the writing. Not the background story or the main plot, but the side characters. The way they behave, especially. It's impressive how much they've done using sound effects, animations, screen shake and caps lock at the most appropriate moments! 
The main plot I didn't care much about, really. The background story was also a bit vague, so take it or leave. But the character interactions were really good.

The worst aspect is really the game itself. It gets especially bad by the end, if you try to find all the coins.

For one, the movement is rather bland for flying. Really, it feels exactly like a walking character, only you can walk up and down. There was one moment where the flying went over the top (in a good way), but that particular section was an infuriating mini-game with a few very important problems that it removes any of the joy in the flying. So yeah, the feeling of flying is not here at all.

Then, there's the main mechanic, where you can carry one character that shoots differently. This isn't used very creatively either, they're almost like "keys". Sometimes you have to destroy a piece of armor with one character and then switching to kill the moster, stuff like that. The mechanic is a bit awkward, but they've implemented some handy shortcuts that make the experience mostly painless. Still doesn't make it very good, only prevents it from being very bad.

The shooting controls were especially bad. Trying to change characters (shoulder buttons) while flying (left analog) and aiming (right analog) and dodging (X) and repeatedly shooting (right trigger) makes it very clumsy. Add to that the imprecise aiming of the analog stick with an weird auto-aim that sometimes focuses on exactly the wrong thing. Heh.

At the end, collecting the coins is a mess, since you're only given X/Y coins you have/need for each area. During the normal playthrough, the game often closes doors behind you too, which is infuriating. I wanted to explore two paths, but accidentally chose the main path, being locked out from the alternative one. Once I got back (after finishing the section and moving on with the story, etc. etc.), I didn't really remember where anything was. 
The game also relies on lots of fake walls for this. Overall, it was just not fun at all. The game also lacks a way of teleporting between areas, making the whole process more painful. Wouldn't recommend going for the extra coins, the reward isn't worth all the hassle.

Honestly, the gameplay wasn't very good. But I'd say the writing, artstyle and music make up for it. At least to make it an enjoyable experience. Given how good the art and music are, I was expecting an equally good game, but that seems to have been somewhat neglected. 

Not a game I was terribly excited playing, but there are certainly noteworthy aspects!

41906616.review:
[h1]Mister Owlboy[/h1]

[b]Owlboy is an adventure game with beautiful pixel-art graphics, great soundtrack and well-written story.[/b] The controls on PC are also really good and there are no problems while playing with mouse and keyboard.

[b]Not only skies[/b]

The world in Owlboy is not very big, but every location is different. You will fly through cities, skies and ancient temples while on your way to solve the mystery behind Pirates attack. Every location is really well designed and there are no tough arcade (not related to fighting) elements here, like in Hollow Knight for example. You will enjoy some nice views, sometimes solve mini puzzles, but that's all.

[b]Owlboy can be finished in less than 10 hours.[/b] If you want to get all the achievements, you'll spend 2 or 3 more hours, since it's only about revisiting previous locations and collecting missed coins. Unfortunately, there is no replay value in this game. 

[b]Owls can hurt![/b]

In case of fighting this game is quite unique, because we are mostly fighting… by our companions. There are 3 of them and each is slightly different. One has fast, but quite weak gun, second one has very powerful, but slow gun, and third one can stun enemies. We unlock all of them with time, but what is the most interesting, we can switch between our companions all the time so there are many possibilities to deal with our enemies in almost every situation.

There are many mini bosses and closed room survival combats in Owlboy, but it's nothing very hard to be honest. Checkpoints are also very often, so after dying you will very likely start over in the same location or room. There is no difficulty level to choose and whole game is quite easy. 

[b]Summary[/b]

If you are looking for a challenge, Owlboy is not for you. [b]But if you are looking for a pleasant experience and you are into old-style adventure games, then you must try this one.[/b] Take a look at some screenshots and if you think you'll like it, don't think twice. Grab it and enjoy this little gem.

[b]8/10[/b]

Owlboy is a beautiful game all around.  The art is well crafted with wonderful detail.  Each place and scene feels real and unique, and displays the tone of the environments well.  

This game combines beautiful art and music with well crafted gameplay and level design to create a wonderful story.  The characters have wonderful depth, and the world is believable, easily sucking you in.

The gameplay itself is well paced, never wearing itself thin, while also lingering around enough to give you a satisfactory taste of what it has to offer.  The level design does a fantastic job at teaching and guiding without feeling pushy or blunt.

What I really love about the levels were the dynamic range of styles.  Most areas are a good balance between simple puzzles and tougher enemy encounters, but some were more stealth based, or more action packed.  All areas felt unique, but none ever felt out of place.  This is especially true with the pirate infiltration.  It's a true stealth sequence which seems strange for such a game, but it feels true to what the game is as a whole.

The story is crafted in a beautiful way, being both simplistic yet deep.  Otis is a lovable character who has so much charm and personality.  In spite of him never stating a word of dialogue, you know who he is, and what he stands for.  Otis' friends also show wonderful personality, each one unique to the others, and yet completing each other in a beautiful way.

The music also needs a special round of applause, being near the top of my list of the best soundtracks to date.  The mix of orchestral and electronic bridge the gap of pixel and modern art, and the tone of each piece captures the essence of each moment perfectly.

Over all, this is a game worth picking up.  If you enjoy story driven games with solid gameplay at its back, this is a good game for you.  For the 8-10 hours this game offers, you'll be invested through them all.  In spite of the major issues I had through 60+% of the game, I refused to pick it up until I hit the end.  I would've willingly played the entire game like that if I had to.

There are some issues here. 

The developer made a game about friendship and determination in a world about ancient technology and anthropomorphized animals. 

I just described about every anime ever made. Are there giant robots? Yes there are.

Cliche, however, is not the problem. Heart is. 

Whoever made this has a lot of heart. They wanted to make a game that has a lot of heart. They want us to cheer for and weep for our characters. They want it bad.  

In short: This game is extensively melodramatic. 

Owlboy is probably going to run you less than ten hours, but in that time the developer tries to establish truly strong relationships. It would take a mighty feat of storytelling to do this. And, in some places, D-Pad studios succeeds.

But, mostly not. I felt yanked around narratively.

There are other caveats that should be mentioned. 

The controls are stifling. Never before has flying been so frustrating. As soon as I discovered dodging I felt the need to spam it constantly. Because, unlike flying, dodging is responsive. I tried not to. I hate actions that make an experience more... gamey, but I rolled my way through most of this thing. Kinda like Dark Souls.

You know what else is like Dark Souls? Dying and being launched back to the beginning of a puzzle or fight (Some of which can be long). Being forced to watch parts (you can skip most) of cutscenes again. There were times where I needed to put the controller down. 

Difficult sections never succeeded at platforming, and the controls (and poor floppy Owlboy) made me want to scream.

So, why the recommendation? 

Because this is a work of art. Not a great piece of gameplay. 

No amount of tactile or literary failings could change the soul of this game.

From the gorgeous art stylings to the soppy storyline, this is special. Whoever made this clearly had a dream. Every bit of this thing oozes personal-touch. And though I am predisposed to not liking it, I walked away from the ending with a smile.

Yes, issues. 

Yes, worth it. 

There is some true beauty here.

There is something worth noting in the music. I'm listening to the soundtrack at this very moment. It has a strong orchestral soundtrack. It's lovely.

Owlboy is one of the most charming and nostalgia inducing games I've ever played. It feels like a game right out of my childhood, something I would've played on my GameBoy Advance as a kid. The fact that this game also had me nearly in tears on multiple occassions, a talent not many games are able to do, speaks volumes for its story and characters.

I fully enjoyed my time playing Owlboy. The bosses were a little intense at times, especially toward the end, but the rest of the experience was absolutely delightful and heartbreaking all in one neat little package. This is a story where the villan will change, and the ending will twist and surprise you. You'll laugh, you'll cry, and you'll hopefully enjoy this game just as much as I did.

You play as Otus, a mute owl outcast shunned by his own mentor and neighbors, on a quest with his friends to save their floating island home from pirates. Along the way there are upgrades to buy, coins to find, puzzles to solve, a minigame to beat, and an open world to explore for secrets. Everything about this story is unlikely, from the characters you meet to the relationships they form with each other, and I [i]loved[/i] it. 

The storyline was heartwrenching. There are happy moments, [spoiler]but not many happy resolutions to the main conflicts[/spoiler], and that's something most games like this won't do. You know a game is good when you start to tear up after [spoiler]one of the villain's henchmen realizes too late he wants to change his ways, and dies[/spoiler]. There are many moments that bring a tear to your eye, even ones you wouldn't expect. This was a beautiful and amazing experience I wish I could forget just so I could play it again.

The music is beautiful, the graphics - though pixelated - are still engaging and wonderful to look at. There were times I forgot it was even a pixelated game, because the world is just so vibrant and gorgeous to look at. The mechanics are strange at first but once you get used to them everything runs very smoothly. I play on an Xbox controller and mainly had issues with the lock-on aiming system and flying when I meant to jump. The puzzles and boss fights were never so hard I couldn't figure them out, at least with a bit of trial and error.

If you love games in this art style, if you want the best nostalgia trip you'll ever find, or if you love owls like I do, absolutely play this game. It is downright amazing, and I loved every second of it.

I really wanted to like this game. I love the art, the music, the characters, the story... but the gameplay takes all that away from me. 

1. The single biggest problem is that tapping your "jump" button enables AND disables your fly/glide ability. Directional Influence meanwhile, (up on your joystick) only enables the same ability - and far less consistently. I am still working on the final boss area, but i've lost all of my momentum and joy for life by repeatedly cancelling my perfectly-timed-platform-glides, and then repeatedly failing to activate the same glides with my DI. 

2. There's no map of the areas. There's a logical map online, which helped collect all the coins, but that is another silly oversight for a game that relies heavily on visual appeal.

3. Most of the gameplay is steering and mashing your trigger buttons. It's a beautiful and nostalgic setting, but it got old for me when i kept losing track of how to get to a specific dungeon or area inside a dungeon. 

4. The cannon. It is just a "play it til your fingers have it memorized" minigame, and was completely joyless for me. 

But hey, that's just me. If you're not a completionist and you want a bite-sized taste of metroidvania, this is a very pleasant game overall. I just have to be picky when I see things done so-freaking-close to right.

40581235.review:
Owlboy is a game that achieves perfection in nearly every way. From its gripping and fast-paced story, to interesting characters, to unique and engaging gameplay, to beuatiful artwork and locations, there's a lot to love in Owlboy.

The absolute best thing about Owlboy is its story. I don't want to spoil it for anybody that hasn't yet experienced it, but I will say that Otus (the main character) is a flawed character that tries his hardest to do what he can to help, but in the end it's questionable if he's actually the hero. Owlbody explores a story that very few storytellers try to tell, and it works perfectly here.

Aside from the story's artisitc merits, the game is well-paced with an engaging story. Cutscenes are neither too short or too long and are spaced the perfect amount between gameplay sections. What this leads to is a constant feeling of progression and engagement in the game. Cutscenes are also enjoyable due to the great cast of quirky characters. The only downside is that this is not a long RPG, so there is no time for any real character development outside of the main character, but even without that, I still felt an attachment to most of the characters and the lesser characters are funny and charming.

A good story can't stand on its own without good gameplay though, and Owlboy delivers that. The gameplay feels fresh and unique, borrowing elements from platformers and twin-stick shooters. Exploration is fun with some light puzzles and combat, although the game is quite linear with the only thing off the beaten path are some coins that are used for upgrades, but you'll get all of the upgrades without spending forever searching for fake walls. I think where the gameplay really shines is in the boss fights, which feel quite numerous and none are alike. They're also where any of the challenge in the game lies, as the exploration sections are quite relaxed. Boss fights feel intense, but aren't overly challenging. I think I died to most of them, but once you get them down, none of the fights last that long honestly.

All-in-all, Owlboy is a very solid package. With its unique and engaging story to its gameplay that feels like its own combined with beautiful visuals as you can see in screenshots above, the complaints I have of the game aren't enough to take away from Owlboy's solid core elements. The game feels a little short with it taking me 6.5 hours to finish, but they were a solid 6.5 hours and I never felt disengaged or bored. The secret areas for 100% coin completion don't lead to any meaningful reward and require you to either use a guide or to go to every previously visited area and literally bump your head against every wall to see which one you can pass through. It could have really used more visual clues for hidden paths. The final cutscene leaves you with questions that you are supposed to answer by reloading your save after the credits, which is strange, but it actually ties into the story of the game.

The biggest hurdle for anybody interested in this game will be the $25 price tag. I can't answer for you if that's too high a price to pay for a 6.5 hour game, but not every experience should be evaluated by its price per hour. Owlboy will be one of the handful of games that I remember for a long time due to its unique story, so I strongly uge you to check it out. If not for $25, then definitely during a sale.

Owlboy es un juego relativamente corto, a mi parecer de la duración ideal. Si miras la media en la web "HowLongToBeat" te dirá que pasártelo de forma tranquila equivale a una inversión de unas 8h de juego. No está nada mal.

[h1]Mi opinión[/h1]

          Como persona relativamente metida en el mudillo de la creación de videojuegos, llevaba siguiendo bastante tiempo el desarrollo de este juego por parte de D-Pad Studios, y siempre me encantó la estética. El arte es maravilloso, muy pulido y bonito, las animaciones son muy llamativas y entendibles.

          Este año por fin lo compré y empecé a jugarlo y es de los pocos juegos que han conseguido engancharme de esta manera, tanto que pude pasarmelo en una semana aún siendo sesiones cortitas (9h en total).

          La historia te atrapa. Te hace sentir bien cuando intenta hacerlo, y cuando quiere hacerte sentir mal, lo consigue. La sensación de aventura es maravillosa, entre otras cosas gracias a la música, que también es una gran obra artística. Los personajes tienen evolución y están bien logrados, y en varios momentos te mete un plot-twist que te deja con los ojos como platos, o te da un golpe duro y te enseña que [b]no siempre todo sale bien.[/b]

           A mi parecer, aún siendo un juego indie hecho por un equipo bien pequeño, este juego es una obra maestra, y todo el mundo debería jugarlo alguna vez en su vida y disfrutar de la sensación de ser un búho en este mundo tan maravilloso. Eso no quita que tenga sus fallos. Veamos:

[h1]Lo bueno[/h1]

[list]
      [*]La música
      [*]El arte y la animación
      [*]La historia y su narración
      [*]Las mecánicas de juego: son fáciles de entender y no demasiadas, en ningún momento vas a no saber qué hacer.
      [*]Los controles: están perfectamente ejecutados y a los minutos de estar jugando te harás a ellos y los usarás de forma inconsciente (como debería ser)
      [*]Los personajes
      [*]La duración
[/list]

[h1]Lo malo[/h1]

[list]
      [*]La dificultad: el juego no está del todo bien balanceado. Hay partes que son muy difíciles, y eso está bien, es un juego relativamente exigente, y no llega a lo injusto en ningún momento. Mi problema son las batallas finales. Los bosses al final se resumen en morir tres veces, encontrar el exploit y aprovecharlo. Ejemplo: quedarse en una esquina mientras ataca, y cuando deje de hacerlo disparar. Repetir. 

          Ahora bien, el juego sabe esto, y por eso añade una segunda fase del monstruo que evita de todas las formas que puede que te pongas en la esquina. ¿Si los desarrolladores saben que prácticamente todos los ataques de la fase uno se evitan de la misma forma, por qué no lo evitan? ¿Cómo es que las partes normales llegan a ser tanto más dificiles que los jefes finales?

          Hay una de las batallas, en cambio, que me parece maravillosa. (Sin spoilers). Si descubres cómo explotar la mecánica pertinente, la batalla se convertirá en un espectáculo a todos los niveles. Sin perder toda su dificultad, consigues encontrar la manera de evitar la muerte usando cierto arma, y entonces la lucha se convierte en un baile perfecto, en una coreografía violenta y coordinada, rápida y certera. Es increíble. Sólo por eso merecería la pena el juego.

          Entonces llegamos al segundo punto:

      [*][b]El final:[/b] Mucho plot-twist, sí. Pero, ¿qué hay del destino?

          Este es el momento en el que si no has jugado el juego aún y sigues leyendo, tal vez quieras dejar de hacerlo ahora. No son grandes spoilers, pero sí pistas.

          La parte final de Owlboy me decepcionó en gran medida. No me arrepiento en absoluto de haberlo jugado, me encantó, y además lo importante es el viaje, no el final. El juego te cuenta una historia entera maravillosa, la hila a la perfección y luego: ¡Zas! La corta por la mitad y te dice "¡Ahá! ¡Esa no te la esperabas! ¿Eh?". Y en efecto, probablemente no lo hicieras. La batalla final es algo totalmente inpredecible, y aún no siendo una mala, no tiene grandes mecánicas aparte de obligarte a usar todo lo que tienes. Se queda muy atrás en comparación con las otras, y eso ya es decir. Y más en comparación a la anteriormente destacada, a mi parecer. 

         Lo que más me molesta de este capítlo final es la falta de destino. Desde el principio sabes que la batalla final va a pasar, te intentas imaginar cómo será, imaginas que será horriblemente dificil debido a la potencia de tu adversario, incluso te da miedo. Y entonces, Owlboy te lanza el guión a la cara y su "¡Sorpresa!", después de todo, acaba convertido en un "¡Pues te fastidias!".

          El prólogo deja muchos cabos sueltos, quizá para dejar el final abierto a una secuela, pero no insinúa que vaya a haberla. La historia es autoconclusiva pero a la vez... No. Te deja con preguntas, pero no necesariamente con ganas de más.

[/list]

[h1]En conlusión[/h1]

         Si estás dudando: juégalo. En serio. Hazlo. Es una obra maestra. Vas a disfrutar cada detalle. Va a llenarte. Juégalo, y hazlo hasta el final. Merece muchísimo la pena, a pesar de todo.

         Owlboy es definitivamente uno de mis juegos favoritos por todo lo que ofrece. Lo volvería a jugar tres veces más y sería un placer, y probablemente lo volvería a disfrutar como la primera vez. 

         Mi más sincera enhorabuena a los integrantes de D-Pad Studios, que les costó tantísimo tiempo terminar esta obra de arte. 

        Ah, por cierto, sí, se juega muy bien con mando. Y ahora lo tenéis también en la switch, así que no sé a que esperáis para darle caña.

[b][u]TO SUM UP:[/u] Owlboy[/b] isn't perfect. It is however beautiful, emotional, heartfelt, moving, wonderfully made and – overall – a fantastic experience. If you somehow missed this one, I strongly suggest that you go ahead and give it a try.

[b][u]FULL REVIEW:[/u] Owlboy[/b] is, above all, two things: it's the first hi-bit game I ever played and, more importantly, it's the game which made me fall in love with hi-bit games in general. Its world is absolutely astonishing, crafted with visible care and composed entirely out of pixels. Its characters are lovingly childish, yet well written and relatable; especially the game's silent protagonist, Otus, who – even though he is unable to say a single word (or rather to display a single word on screen) – is able to express his emotions better than many I know. Owlboy's music and sound design also play an incredibly important part since (following in the footsteps of old-school games which the hi-bit genre stems from) none of the characters are voiced. Fortunately, the game's musical themes are equally brilliant as the rest of it, providing emotional background where it's needed and creating an ambience that sometimes makes you feel like a small kid going on an adventure with your friends. Speaking of friends, I've never played a game able to depict friendship in the way Owlboy does. I often felt like the creators had succesfully tapped into some mysterious source of pure emotion and had simply decided to spill it all over this game. Simply put: Owlboy is a wonder. Although not all of it is sunshine and rainbows and some parts are incredibly frustrating and excrutiatingly painful as far as level design is concerned, I believe it to be a game able to charm anyone, provided they give it a chance and enough time.

I had my eyes on the Owlboy for a while now and I was looking forward to seeing what a passionate group of ambitious 5 developers working for many many years can pull off. Sadly, I am disappointed. There is a lot to appreciate in Owlboy, but all of it is superficial. Music is nice, the art is detailed and impressive. That much you can tell by looking at the screeshots. A lot of effort was put into the project, but unfortunately it doesn’t deliver and engaging experience. Art is nice, but isn’t tied to anything engaging or fun.

Gameplay is the biggest weakness of Owlboy. How do you make a platformer interesting when you character can fly without limitations? Owlboy didn’t find an answer for this question. You can move in any direction you want, for the most part without any restrictions. Flying isn’t fun – there is no mechanic there, and movement is very slow and sluggish. Levels are dull, usually either completely open spaces, or tight corridors. Your movement doesn’t get expanded at all throughout the gameplay. 

Combat is just as weak. Owlboy can’t really fight to well, but he has buddies he can summon and carry, while they shoot. They differ from each other, but don’t provide interesting gameplay and all are unsatisfying to “use”. Gameplay wise you carry three boring guns, which you drop whenever you get hit. Early on there is some experimentation with enemies which can be hit only by certain characters, but the idea gets ditched very quickly. Overall, Owlboy loves to start introducing some gameplay ideas before ditching them completely after introduction.
Story isn’t engaging either. It tries to be more depressing than your usual colourful platformers, but it works just as well as a Mario game dealing with a cancer – its not fun, its not sad, just kinda weird and misplaced.

Overall a weak, boring title. There are a lot more fun, creative and emotionally charged titles out there.

[h1] tldr: I think there’s a great game hidden in here somewhere, but it’s just not able to shine through the boring gameplay and poor level design. It’s enjoyable, but not much more. It’s worth playing, but I wouldn’t recommend it.

owlboy [/h1]

Owlboy is definitely a well made game. Look at those graphics and that 10 year dev cycle. Those didn’t go towards nothing, because there is a lot of polish in this game, especially in the graphics. It’s got possibly the best pixel-art I’ve ever seen. That works well for the sense of whimsical adventure it seems to be going for, and it succeeds! For like, an hour or so. Unfortunately, it slowly falls apart as you realize…

[h1] the gameplay’s kinda boring [/h1]

This is really what kills the game, honestly. The flying mechanic is err...it’s basically just being able to float in mid-air and move wherever you want. Just float. No sense of momentum, just one fixed speed, hovering in mid-air. That’s kinda underwhelming, but clearly not what the game was about. It’s about the sense of adventure from exploring the world, fighting baddies and enemies along the way! And...those are kinda boring, too. 

Puzzles are fun, but slow and easy, making progressing in the long term something of a bore. The mechanics are great when you’re introduced to them, but slowly become frustrating over time. Combat is just a chore. The characters/weapons you have are particularly weak against the enemies. Owlboy isn’t a particularly hard game, but it’s definitely a frustrating one because the enemies are ludicrously spongy. You’re just going to be floating around and clicking constantly on enemies, occasionally moving about to dodge attacks. Or using [i]that[/i] character near the end of the game.

[h1] and the level design isn’t particularly good [/h1]

Even if we’re ignoring the rather linear world, the level design still isn’t that good. Owlboy would be better described as an NES Metal Gear/Strider style game. There's tonnes of dialogue. So much so that you'll spend about half your time reading text boxes. 39911489.review:
Does a game need to be upbeat to be fun? Certainly not, as titles like Inside or The Cat Lady will tell you. But melancholy must be managed carefully, lest it drag down a game in ways not intended. Owlboy is a game that would appear at first glance to be entirely outside such considerations, what with its bright graphics and lush environments. But the story woven through this story-driven adventure is one chock full of sadness and disappointment, and it’s just as jarring as you’re thinking. It might be forgivable, too, if the gameplay was half as compelling as the art.

Otus is a young owl, living in the floating village of Vellie under the tutelage of the local master Asio. He’s conveniently mute, which makes it all the easier for his perfectionist mentor to blame him for anything that goes wrong. And things go very wrong when pirates show up in their peaceful burg to nick an artifact of great power. Otus knows something is afoot and flaps off to stop the pirates, along with some pals he can carry along to help him out. The journey takes him to a massive aerial city, a forgotten stronghold of the ancient owl civilization, and further as he struggles to redeem himself and uncover the secrets of the pirate assault.

All of that should sound like the makings of a fine adventure, except that bit about being blamed for things. I wish I could downplay this aspect of the game but it’s actually a cornerstone of the story, and something that soured me on the game right from the start. The opening tutorial is posed as Asio teaching Otus how to handle basic skills as an owl and help out around the village. But it’s designed so that you’ll fail everything you’re instructed to do, and earn some withering disapproval from your mentor. That’s just the tip of the iceberg though, as Otus ends up bullied by the other village residents, blamed for events he has no control over, discouraged from assisting during a crisis, and ignored when sharing information. Worst of all he gets guilt-tripped for a catastrophe where he was the only individual anywhere close to stopping it, and which proved to be absolutely inevitable.

Does that sound like a good time? Of course not. Talented storytellers know not to beat down their protagonists without some kind of hope or relief, but here there is neither. Just as I thought Otus was getting out from under all the pressure and assumptions about his competence, one of his friends turns on him. You spend an hour on the trail of a key item and keep it out of the hands of your foes, only for them to steal it away off-screen. For every step of your journey, someone is going to doubt you or discourage you or straight-up blame you for something out of your control. It starts out tiresome and only becomes moreso, and distracts mightily from what could otherwise be a pretty interesting story.

The gameplay at least provides a little levity from the ball and chain of the story, but only temporarily. As the titular owl-boy, Otus can fly freely across the airy realms and carry items to huck at enemies or drop on switches. He can also carry allies, and you’ll meet up with three who provide useful attacks and powers for overcoming challenges along the way. Most of the game is spent puzzling your way to destinations, using switches or strange creatures to clear the way. There are enemies to fight, however, and while they start out simple enough they soon become greater annoyances than your mentor. Late-game enemies will swarm you, juggle you to death, and block attacks from the easiest angles. Their gimmicks are poorly telegraphed too, which can lead to some frustrating deaths just from trying to learn what they do. I lost entirely too much time to a group of monkeys in a lava cave because they moved swiftly and getting hit at all meant being bounced into magma and dying instantly.

Put simply, nothing in Owlboy is designed even half as well as the art. Enemies move and attack too fast and can easily knock you into other hazards or deathtraps. Gimmicks like stealth sections or having to stay in the light have ill-defined rules and consequences. One of your key attacks is on an absurdly long cooldown and must be used to solve some common puzzles. The camera follows you until you reach the edge of an area and then waits for you to push past the transition, but enemies can hide off the edge and hit you before you see them. The list goes on and on, and after maybe four hours or so I was getting aggravated enough to quit for good.

Even the exploration suffers from short-sighted design. As lush and detailed as the game world is, it proves to be very, very small. There’s one village, a central hub area of wide-open vertical spaces, and pretty much just three large dungeons off of that. Backtracking in inevitable and sometimes the game will send you on detours just to kill time, like one teleporter that takes you back to the hub just to make you turn it back on so you can return to where you were. The themes of the game make it feel like it should be a grand journey across a sprawling world, but I never felt like I was going any significant distance, and the lack of a map made it hard to get a good picture of the world in my mind. There’s not even much point to exploring either, because all you’ll find are chests of coins and maybe one of three special tokens. You’re not going to find any upgrades or powers or collectibles even, rendering this one a pale imitation of a metroidvania.

It’s honestly distressing how much potential is lost here, especially in light of the game’s magnificent aesthetic. The hand-drawn pixel art is incredibly detailed and lovingly animated, which gives the entire world so much depth and character. There’s clearly a lot of thought put into the strange creatures and mysterious ruins you’ll come across, which makes it all the more frustrating that the story and gameplay can’t keep up. Owlboy feels like a trap, a game made to look warm and inviting that then slaps you around and ridicules you once you buy in. That awful intro set the stage for the further frustrations suffered throughout the game, and no amount of pretty art can make up for such offenses.

There's coins and secret walls to be found if you want to look for them, but this game is more about telling a story than exploring a world. The more tense music in the game is done with synthesizer or violin which might appeal to some but it's not my favorite choice; by no means am I saying I didn't enjoy the music in Owlboy though, the opposite is true with my favorite tracks being the Tropos day and Mesos themes. Tropos' theme inspires exploration and my only gripe is that leaving the area even for a moment gets rid of the music. Mesos, on the other hand, is this vast snowscape which also serves as a low point in the game for the characters, this is reflected in the piano giving you a colder tone but also the determination to fight on. The gameplay is fantastic (as most things in this game are). I played Owlboy on a keyboard/mouse setup and it's probably the only 2d "platformer" that feels natural on keyboard. The mouse allows for precision aiming which is important (especially with the 3rd character) and Owlboy himself flows quite smoothly. I like the idea that your character isn't a physical fighter himself, at least not to the point of wounding adversaries any harder than what is required to stun them. A couple of other small things like how Otus (the protagonist) is canonically mute makes my heart smile as it gives a justification for him being a silent protagonist. 


There are a couple of things I openly disliked about the game, 2 specifically. The first thing is the bossfights; I liked the intensity of a couple of fights, but overall I thought they were lacking something. A great example of this is the last boss in the game whom you're supposed to defeat using each of your 3 supporting characters which is a great idea on paper; in practice this part is less impactful than expected, there's no noticable difference from swapping between the 3 characters in regards to how they affect the boss except that one of them does his part with one blast. I would've preferred for this fight to utilize the different mechanics of the three supporting characters and maybe allow Otus himself to deal the damaging blow as this to me would've been a more impactful and satisfying bossfight. 

The second thing I didn't like was the fact that despite the world being "decently sized" it didn't feel as big as I think I would've wanted it to be. The biggest issue I had with this was near the earlier part of the game where the game gives you access to the capital city of the world you live in but most of the exploring for that part is done inside of a pirate ship. The city itself is destroyed before you can do anything about it but with you seeing almost none of this area it feels like a lot of wasted potential. I felt that this could've been remedied by maybe making it so that  the characters had to come back to the city after the carnage and could explore its ruins. I know Tropos functions as a central hub but I found myself wanting more out of it and not getting enough out of the stuff that was there. The things that were there just seemed thrown about in no particular order, sprinkle a couple of enemies over here, leave a few healing foods down here, etc. Functionally though, it gets the job done.


It is important to understand that even though I criticized these couple of points in great detail, I did so because these were legitamately the only 2 aspects of the game I could think of that I didn't wholeheartedly enjoy. I said at the beginning of the review that Owlboy is easily in my top 3 games of all time and I stand by that. It is one of the only games that has made me feel so much empathy for the characters that there was actually a point that I cried. Maybe that's because I'm a big baby but I like to think that it's due to fantastic storytelling and relatable characters. Owlboy is more than a game, it's a work of art; a beautiful work of art. A masterpiece. I've never played anything like it. I love this game.


I give Owlboy a 9.8/10

Owlboy is a platformer. You play as Otus, an Owl who is academically not inclined and tends to bungle things up. You start off in the town of Vellie (play on Valley). Along the way, your hometown gets attacked by pirates looking for things called the Relics. Not much is explained about the Relics throughout the game except that they have great power. 

Gameplay-wise, WASD keys for direction, Double W lets you fly, Spacebad lets you roll. Picking up your companions and left mouse click allows you to use their abilities . E.g. Getty shoots short-range bullets and destroys rocks, Alphonse shoots a musket and lights fires, Twig fires webs and web pulls.

Conclusion, I am torn between giving it a negative for the sub-par ending and a positive for the good start. You can see from the ending that effort was put into the beginning but the ending was hastily cobbled together. Normally, I would not give an incomplete game a positive review as this encourages the practice of making half a game and then neglecting the rest. However, I will just leave the half-finished portion as a caveat instead. Try the game but note that it's unfinished.

Caveat Emptor : This is an incomplete game play it with your eyes wide open.

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. Raincloud Missions
I love moving the raincloud and squeezing it to get water out.

2. Different Companion Abilities
Getty shoots short-range bullets and destroys rocks, Alphonse shoots a musket and lights fires, Twig fires webs and web pulls. This is a basic gaming cliche but it works.

The graphics remind me of Pokemon.

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. The Lacklustre Ending
It was so horrible. The Relics were never explored. The full range of companions were never completed. The boss battles deteriorated into a a spoilt CRT TV battle where Solus splits into Red, Green and Blue.

Oh, big bad baddy, then you never actually fight him.

The white-black ending is pretty much evidence of the cobbling together of the design.

Honestly one of my favorite games I've ever played. I love the artwork, I love the quirky characters, I love the story. Playing as Otus was a 10/10 experience for me, I couldn't reccomend this game enough.
I feel this game is more for the visual and story than the actual combat, but the combat system worked very well for not being based entirely on that. 

Now, I have read a couple negative reviews on this game. And I can see what they mean, but I found no issue looking right past those aspects they mentioned. One bad review said something along the lines of "After putting 8 hours into this game, I don't feel inclined to ever pick it back up again." And I understand that, in fact that's how I am about this game. I experienced the story my own way the first time, and i enjoyed it so much I would rather not accidentally speedrun a second playthrough.

A second bad review said "the combat system is too punishing for when you get hit. you get hit, you drop your friend and fall." And that's exactly right. But, you have to take into account that (minor spoiler) Otus isn't a full blown Owl yet. He's still learning and growing, not to mention he flies with a cloak instead of actual wings like other Owls. I guess that Otus is about in his teens. So, if a 16 year old boy could pick up someone at least his own weight and fly, I would agree that the combat system is too punishing. But it's actually fair. It's not easy for a 160 lb boy to pick up a 160 lb boy. (Another minor spoiler) Otus even picks up Alphonse who is easily triple Otus's weight, at least. And let's say you do get hit and drop your buddy, you can press 1 button or scroll your scroll wheel to teleport them to you. With that in mind, I easily look past the "punishing combat system."

Ignore the negative reviews, this game is definitely worth the price. If I could forget the game and replay it brand new, I would without a second thought.

I was so sure I was going to like this game.

The art is really top notch. There's detail everywhere, the character designs are brimming with personality, and the environment is beautiful. The music is also excellent.

The gameplay... is not on the same level. The controls are just a bit clunky, the main character maybe a touch too slow. I played with a controller, and found that trying to aim, fire, and roll to avoid attacks at the same time was incredibly awkward -- it requires you to use the right stick, a button, and the trigger all on the same side of the controller. Alternating between the two is, again, clunky, and slows the pace down further. 

When you're first given control of Otus (the Owlboy), you're in a wide open area of floating islands and the movement speed/handling isn't. Then you start getting into narrow corridors, and it becomes a drag. In the larger outdoor areas, I see a lot of what I wanted -- exploration, great scenery, collectables to hunt down and some enemies.

Some of the boss fights are really fun!  In others, it can be difficult to tell if you're doing the right thing to move the fight forward. In particular, one boss needs you to shoot off his 'hat' twice. The hat looks like a dozen other things you've had to pick up so far. Do you pick this up? No, and you'll get hit by the boss for trying.

There were a lot of instances of this kind of problem, mostly small, where I couldn't tell what the game wanted me to do. Sometimes the detail of the graphics itself was the issue. Enemies that aren't obvious against a detailed background, for instance, or lava pits in a mini boss arena that I didn't realize were unconvered until I fell straight in. If you read the game's cues correctly on the first try, everything feels simple, but if it's not clicking it can be hard to tell if you're having an issue with execution or understanding.

The 'set pieces' were what really got to me, though. Corridor chases, stealth sequences, and the thing that made me quit: ride a lava worm through a spinning corridor, avoiding rocks. The controls are confusing, the handling is poor, and I was getting both dizzy and frustrated with repeated attempts. 

If the controls don't bother you, and you're okay with the weird grab bag mixture of puzzle/set piece/run and gun/boss/exploration/collectable hunt... I guess give it a try! If what I've described sounds unfocused and unenjoyable, then definitely take a pass on it.

I've put down and picked up the game several times now, and I'm just not having fun with it. I wish I could, but clearly it's not for me.

Taking place in a fantasy world of floating islands, players control Otus, a young, mute owl. What starts with Otus and his best friend Geddy pursuing a thief quickly grows into the discovery of a violent force that threatens all of civilization. Characters have inner conflicts and regrets, certain moments get metaphysical and surreal.

The game’s completely pixelated 2D art style is also a wonder to behold. Environments, characters, and effects all look meticulously detailed, inspired, appealing and distinct. To make up for lacking voice acting, character animation is fluid, varied and charming, with unique hand drawn motions for everyone down to the smallest bit player.

The gameplay, presentation, and overall imagination hit bullseyes. Otus’s flight abilities  function as you’d expect them to and control great. Otus can also carry and throw numerous objects,  do a quick dodge in any direction, and even perform a melee spin.

If I haven’t made it clear then [b][i]Owlboy[/i][/b] is a true gem. It has a fantastic amount of retro charm and genuine heart and have a wonderful and creative gameplay - among the best I’ve experienced in recent years.

39665146.review:
I recommend this game not on the sum of its parts, but of specific parts themselves.

As a whole, Owlboy offers a startling small amount in terms of advancing this genre. It feels more of a "last breath" than "youthful fresh air". I keep thinking about the span of development time that the reviewers would not let us forget: A decade. I then turn to the times during my ~8 hour playthrough where I found something not quite as polished as I expect even for (I assume) a small team over a long time. No fast travel (even though there is little reason to backtrack), no map (even though areas/sections are linear), some bosses are frustrating until you learn how to "cheese" them, etc.

The pixels are indeed beautiful. The orchestral soundtrack - while sounding very out-of-place at times - still shines in enough cases to make me believe it was the right choice. The story was traditional at the core while offering a couple twists that keep it from being entirely rote.

Playing this for the first time over a year later after all the hype has gone and "Best of" lists written... I feel conflicted. My sense - and I have no facts to back this up - is that 10 years is a very long time for a game (surely a labor of love) to gestate. During that time tastes change, people come and go, events in the world color your perceptions as a person, you grow older and possibly wiser. Perhaps, you find chances to alter parts of yourself. That correction fixes the initial flaw, but subtly adds another. Owlboy feels like that.

I still must recommend this, if only as something to experience and learn from. The parts that make up the flawed whole are indeed something special.

39591970.review:
A quick note to players, considering a lot of negative reviews mention either of these details. If you are expecting a difficult game, or an exploration game that offers many different paths to make your way through, then Owlboy is probably not for you.

While Owlboy does have a large amount of areas, and quite a lot of open space to fly around and see interesting environments, the majority of the path to progress in the story is pretty linear. There are a handful of side areas to discover, some of which are through fake walls or obtaining collectibles, but the adventure is still pretty linear in where you navigate. For instance, early in the game you will encounter an area that is extremely wide open with a handful of exits noticeable; but you will quickly realize that pretty much only one exit is available, and you return to the area numerous times later on. That is the way most of the bigger areas work for the game, though there are occasional optional paths for collectibles.

Similarly, the game is, for the most part, pretty easy to complete. The game does not utilize save points, but instead tracks your progress at certain time intervals or when you switch between certain rooms. Because of that, even though there are some sections that might be difficult for platforming or destroying enemies, you will usually respawn in the same room or in the previous room.

Also, a couple of things that stood out to me for Owlboy were that the game does not have a world map, nor does it utilize fast travel. Thus, I would recommend playing the game in a short period of time instead of returning to it over and over. While it is generally easy to learn where things are, you might forget if you put the game down for a bit. It can be annoying if you go down a far pathway only to realize that you returned to the wrong area. Without fast travel, you have to go back down the wrong pathway again and try somewhere else. Further, it only takes about 10 hours to finish the game, more or less dependent upon how fast you go through the story and whether you collect coins and tokens.

With those points out of the way, I will say that Owlboy is a pretty interesting game and I enjoyed it more than I expected. I would say that storyline and the art style are clearly the biggest positives for the game, while the gameplay is definitely interesting in the mechanics, though it is not perfect. You can easily judge the visuals from the screenshots and trailers, obviously. There was a lot of work put into the pixel art here, and it made for some very nice scenery to explore. As for the story, it is quite confusing for a while, and technically, there are a lot of open ends by the completion of the game. Many details are still ambiguous even if you unlock the [spoiler]Eternal Sanctuary[/spoiler]. Nevertheless, slowly learning about this world of owls was interesting to me.

Lastly, although maybe a negative note to end on, is that I do not think the game to be as much of a "masterpiece" as many people claim. While I enjoyed the adventure, I'm not sure I would even put the game in my Top 50 list, really. That is not to say that the game is bad, but I am surprised by people saying that it is one of the best games ever.
