I heard a lot about this game, the amount of press this game got from indie fans was amazing, and I was just curious about the game.  This was a 10 year quest with hand drawn graphics and it sounded like an indie darling. 

So I was excited when I finally got a chance to play it, and see how it stacked up. 

After 8 hours I ended up putting down the game and moving on to something else, and it wasn't because I was done.  It was because I didn't really want to see more.   I kept hearing about the art, and.... yes the art is good, but I don't think this is one of the best looking games as people say.  The hand animation and all just didn't resonate with me like I heard it resonate with reviewers.  The pixel art aesthetic has been done in many games, seeing it here is nice, but it's not a novel. 

The art is good but "I spent a long time with a hard process" makes me kind of shrug.  I can see the brilliance of a game like Cuphead but that's because of the hand drawn animation and making it look and feel like 1930s rotoscope technology.   In Owlboy I see a beautiful game, but it feels like it got only a little benefit from the hand drawing everything. 

The story in this game varies, but overall it lacks much of a punch or desire to follow.  You're an Owlboy, there's a evil country that you have to go fight, you need to explore... yada yada.  The story is just going to be your means of conveyance from point A to point B. 

The part though that made me give up this game is the gameplay.  As I played the game, I found my mind thinking about what I wanted the character to do.  Soar through the clouds, fly around, experience real fluid momentum.  Owlboy doesn't want to do that.  In fact I kept trying to remember a game similar to this and it finally struck me.  I wanted to be able to use the abilities the bird Swoop did in Little Big Planet so I felt like I was flying.  Instead Owlboy just feels like a rather ordinary platformer where a character has the Kirby ability to fly (moving the thumbstick around) and dash.    I never felt like an "owl boy" and the game felt very slow and tedious.  

The fact is much of the game play never grabbed me, and just when you think the game is going to do something unique and novel, they give you people who hang on to you and shoot guns.  So while the main character never fires a weapon, everyone else does... joy.   For such a unique and wonderful game, with great art, it feels like the game play got little to no love.  You fly through rings at a very slow speed, you pull up objects out of the ground, and you shoot enemies.  

Owlboy wants to be more, every reviewer seems to have bought into this story of a small indie who spent 10 years hand crafting the art of this game to be perfect, and while that's impressive, I noticed a lot of reviewers having personally spent time with the team.  Maybe they're amazingly wonderful people and charm everyone, maybe they are just burnt out on modern graphics, and either way.  That's all good.  

Yet I'm not the type of person who puts down games, and Owlboy is one of the few good games that I decided I was done playing, not through difficulty, or skill, but through the fact I was just bored with it. 

I ended up being unable to recommend this game.  I know a lot of people really do enjoy it, but to me once I look at the game I played, and the fact they wanted 25 dollars for that experience I shake my head.  That makes it a hard no on recommendation.  However I get that I'm in the minority in this opinion as well.

39138667.review:
[u]General Ratings (on a scale of 1-5)[/u]

[*]GRAPHICS [5.0/5.0]
[*]GAMEPLAY / CONTROLS / DIFFICULTY [5.0/5.0]
[*]MUSIC / SFX [5.0/5.0]
[*]STORYLINE [5.0/5.0]

[u]Detailed Personal Commentary[/u]

[*]GRAPHICS

Luscious retro-style pixel-art abounds. On the surface, this seems like it would have been right at home within the 16 and 32-bit era of console gaming, but exists in a more-refined and polished form. The characters are fun, made up of large sprites with good animations. The attention to detail, such as within their expressions and movements, often made me smile throughout the game.

This care is extended to many other graphical elements as well. For example, the environments elevate parallax scrolling to a high-art. The many layers between foreground and background give a nice sense of depth even though the game stays essentially 2-D. This is further enhanced by lighting effects like shine and fog.

[*]GAMEPLAY / CONTROLS / DIFFICULTY

Overall, I would categorize this game as "action-adventure" in genre, but it is hard to classify it as rigidly following any one style of play. There is platforming, some shoot-em-up like sequences, a few puzzles, etc. However, all of these are integrated together seamlessly and naturally, rather than being merely a pastiche of interesting parts.

The level design is great. They have a good balance in size that invites exploration without causing a sense of overwhelm. The maps of some games are so large that it sometimes becomes tedious to traverse them, especially when they send you on repeated fetch quests. Fortunately, this game does not suffer from either of those defects. Most items are useful to your adventure and are not overly difficult to obtain, so it does not degrade into grinding or mindless collecting.

The controls are fluid and responsive. The only minor quibble I have is that a couple of the characters have two different actions assigned to one button (i.e.: where you press to perform one action and hold to perform another). This sometimes makes it difficult to execute a specific action, but I am not sure how one would alter the control scheme to fix it as all of the controller buttons are already assigned common actions!

If you are a slightly more casual gamer, the difficultly can become a little challenging in some parts, yet is also very forgiving. The life meter is not excessively small, checkpoints are frequent enough, and continues are infinite. It won't feel so impossible that it makes you rage quit, but it won't hold your hand all the way through either.

[*]MUSIC / SFX

The soundtrack is orchestral and quite beautiful. It imparts a cinematic quality to the gaming experience as a whole. I don't know if I would jam to the entire OST separately, as you can tell it is a score to something, but it complements the story perfectly.

The sound effects provide a pleasant nuance to actions. They don't become repetitive or detract from the music.

[*]STORYLINE

The story is well-written. It flows and is easy enough to follow without lacking in realism. The world and its characters are interesting. As I got further into the game, I began to care about them and became concerned about their predicaments. I was even moved emotionally a couple of times.

[spoiler]Your opinion of the ending may change depending upon your interpretation of the last cutscene and how much of the game you have completed, particularly if you have unlocked The Eternal Sanctuary and listened to Noctae. I have my own interpretation of the story, but I will let you draw your own conclusions.[/spoiler]

[u]Summary[/u]

I don't play as many games as I used to, but I really love this one and am glad that I did. I just wish it was longer, as there isn't a lot of replay value. Once you complete it, that's it! In this sense, it is like watching a good movie. You may revisit it sometime in the future, but you probably won't be watching it every other week.

I would recommend it to everyone, with the exception of perhaps the youngest children (under 7), as they may not be able to follow the subtleties of the story or might become overstimulated by its contents. There is some talk of death, cartoon violence, and perilous situations, but no profanity, gore, nudity, or anything like that.

39125679.review:
An easy way to describe Owlboy is to say it's pleasant, even wholesome. Someone less kind might invert those statements and call it saccharine or vapid. The cross-section of those four adjectives is the best quick way I can think of to review the game, but there's just one problem: that's not giving it enough credit.

There's a good chance that the first thing you noticed when you came to this game's store page is how good-looking it is. To my knowledge, Owlboy has the most impressive pixel-based graphics of any video game ever made. The graphics are highly detailed and very 'clean,', a fact which probably explains the majority of the game's nine-year development period. It's certainly not the scope or content that took so long: it's easy to cover everything the game has to offer in under twelve hours. As a matter of fact, the game underwent a lot of the difficulties you would expect from such a long development cycle. Quite a substantial amount of planned content was never made, and entire areas, fully-animated characters, and even complete boss fights were cut.

So far the game might sound like a case of style over substance. That's not quite fair either, because the story is actually very good. It really nails the balance between portraying human weakness and creating characters you want to root for. The heroic characters have major insecurities and they make mistakes that really impact the narrative. Even so, I never found them grating or unsympathetic, partially because they have such unerring strength of spirit. It's easy to have characters mope for too long before they rebound and try again, but Owlboy avoids that pit-trap.

In the case of the main character, Otus, that trait is tied to the themes of the story: redemption and trust. The central idea of the game is that no matter how many and severe your mistakes, you can make up for them if you try. That's probably a bit naive, and there are definitely moments where the characters are too quick to forgive, which makes the story feel sweet to the point where it's hard to suspend disbelief. But that's not too surprising: it's a game about a magical owl child after all, and it's essentially for kids. There's no reason why you couldn't let your five-year-old play this.

Yeah, hateful masochists like myself might leave feeling a bit unsatisfied. Besides the light, simple nature of the story, the game is really easy. For one thing, there's almost no penalty for death. The game drops checkpoints so often that running out of health will often see you transported back to the start of the same room in which you died, with your life-bar filled as a courtesy. Not that you're likely to die often: the enemy attack patterns are simple and you have a lot of health to absorb hits with. The hardest parts of the game are when you have to quickly transfer between carrying an ally and fighting empty-handed, simply because that's kind of awkward to do.

It's understandable to complain about the controls. It wouldn't be a problem to have to carry allies if you didn't regularly have to carry objects too. Shuffling them around can be a little bit of a pain, and the way the character handles takes some getting used to. The shooting works in the dual-stick method, and I recommend using the mouse and keyboard to keep down the annoyance of that aspect.

You also have infinite flight. To be fair, the game is designed so that this isn't such a broken power, but that leads to a lot of the levels being tight and claustrophobic, which defeats the purpose of the flight to some extent. In the more wide-open levels, the game loses a sense of proper constraints, and the areas feel too large to explore comprehensively. Some places in particular are large and wide-open but contain no secrets or coins, and the only way for the player to determine this is to search them manually, which turns out to be a total waste of time. The game rarely finds the happy medium between these two extremes.

Exploring to find all the Bucannary coins is kind of an underdeveloped element of the game. Most of the hidden coins are simply found by flying through false walls, and there is never an instance where the player needs to revisit an older area with newly acquired powers - it doesn't deserve the 'Metroidvania' tag Steam users have given it. The final power-up and a Steam Achievement supposedly require you to gather every coin in the game, except the game sometimes gives you 'extra' chests for killing enemies, another element which just makes the game too easy.

But all that bashing aside, it's still fundamentally competent. The bosses are structured well and running through the levels is fun. It technically has a good difficulty curve in that it goes from easy to less easy as the game moves on.

At this point, you may rightly think my review is just as toothless and middle-of-the-road as the game itself. I would like to return to my earlier statement, that such a claim doesn't give Owlboy enough credit. The final moments of the story are what elevate it. There's an important twist near the end that I have to admit I didn't see coming, although that might say more about me than the game. In the conclusion, the game successfully leaves certain story concepts unexplained while giving the player enough information to come to the 'canonical' interpretation himself (although it does this by not being very subtle with its hints.) Those concepts tell a short side-story that raises questions about the purpose of life and the value of science and technology, and it does so in a way that gives the player some things to think about and expand upon, even if other stories and writers have already explored the same ideas and done it better. It still eventually gets away from being the simple but functional adventure story it seems to be at first.

And that leaves us with just a little housekeeping. The soundtrack is beautiful. It does a great job building atmosphere and enhancing the mood of the story. Finally, I should mention the price. For the length and replayability of the game, it's slightly on the expensive side. You could certainly buy a longer, more challenging, edgier game for less money (Salt and Sanctuary is one example,) but there's a trade that comes with that decision: whatever game it was, it wouldn't look as good as Owlboy.

In so many ways, this game is a masterpiece. The art direction, music, world, and often the gameplay combine to create something that will remain in my memory for a long time. The fact that the world of Owlboy--a world filled with history, humor, and memorable environments and characters--has an internal logic where everything has an explanation and a place is very satisfying; I found myself immersed in this world and truly "swept along". The art design and story are studio Ghibli inspired (fine by me): colorful, aesthetically brilliant design mixed with themes such as the ever popular "finding yourself", non black-and-white motivations, and humans v nature. Little touches--the way you open chests and heal yourself not just by pressing a button; Otus's different facial expressions--end up meaning a lot. The score (by Jonathan Geer) is a masterpiece of videogame sound design which, for this gamer at least, truly evoked feelings and sensations that I simply couldn't believe I was feeling at the age of 28 (and playing this on a toaster MacBook pro while on vacation). It has a wealth of different textures, orchestration, moods, and colors. How much the score strengthens the game cannot be overstated. As an aside, it has been inspiring to hear so many incredible, sophisticated scores in indie games recently, such as those in Hollow Knight, Ori, Banner Saga, and Abzu (both by the incredible Austin Wintory) to name some of my favorites. 


The gameplay is technically competent, sometimes outstanding, and rarely annoying and unintuitive. For instance, a platforming section near the end of the game and several boss battles seemed to me infuriatingly arbitrary (hard as it is to get mad at such a lovable game). Likewise, a section without adequate lighting was a chore--especially given that I think the same mood and effect could have been acheieved with a little more clarity of design. On the other hand, the early hours of flying, exploration, and dungeon crawling are elegantly designed and provide alternating sections of tension and relaxation (not as tense and motoric as, say, Mega Man..not as exploration heavy as Zelda). The combat allows for several tricks which give it a degree of depth. The final portion of the game I can see as being divisive, as some of the freedom and sense of non-linearity to the level design goes out the window; there is however a lore justification for this, so perhaps it is a matter of opinion. The fact that it threatened the gameplay in a small way makes me ambivalent, if not outright disappointed. 



Despite these nitpicks, this was one of the most memorable games I've played in the last..well, ever. Buy it because a) you'll have fun with it, and a2) it is a TRUE work of art, and in my opinion we should all support these kind of developers. The Good:

The Bad: The sad thing about Owlboy is that it fails to be any more than mediocre in every other aspect. 

The controls are clunky. This is one of the most important parts of any game, and with Owlboy, I found myself stumbling through the entire game when it came to the controls. I felt like I never really got used to them.

The puzzles are too easy. There wasn't a single time that the puzzles were challenging. I love the "Aha!" moments of games with puzzles, and sadly this game didn't contain a single one. This was the least challenging part of the game.

The mechanics of the game were often very awkward. There is no one thing that bothered me when it came to the mechanics, but instead a lot of little things. For one,  I would often find myself dying solely because the camera would pan over, and lock to a certain part of the dungeon at inappropriate times. Also, there is no in game map, which most of the time this isn't a problem, but a few times I would completely forget where a certain building is, and spend a good amount of time fflying around searching for it. Another annoyance is that when you are injured, our hero flashes and blinks, often causing me to lose track of where he is within the sometimes chaotic fighting. Finally, one other mechanic that was bothersome after a while was the lack of control during talking scenes, and they were a frequent interruption of gameplay. The flow of the game suffered for it. 

The last thing I want to mention is the storyline. This is a big one. The storyline started off interesting because of the main characters dynamic with his mentor, who  thinks our hero is completely useless, and constantly reminds him so. This really pushes you to try to prove him wrong. Sadly, as the game progresses, you have fewer and fewer reasons to care about what is happening. While the characters had distinct personalities, I never felt particularly attached to any of them. They each had a short background story, and that was that. The storyline itself was a typical "save the world" plot. As the game went on, I never found myself really being driven by the story, and while some people really appreciated the ending of this game, I found it very unsatisfying and was mostly happy the game had ended.

2/5
